column4: Moving into an apartment for 1st time Brings up Past ED issues thought was Over and Done with
column5: Only as a freshman in college, I lost a good amount of weight from the pressure of not only taking required courses but realizing in not making top grades in some of the required courses made me focus so much on studying that I was merely grazing on snacks daily while on campus. Then my outlet at school was my chosen PE classes which gave me a way out w/o acting on harming myself as I realized that Chem 101 was really not meant for me. Then in meeting my college counselor to go over a new agenda and schedule w/ a completely new career goal in mind and totally different major coursework on my plate for the next semester was a new trigger for trying to gain Total Control over my feelings of inadequacy over certain failures happening b4 my very eyes as I experienced failure in school this was new for me. I had always been a good student. But college courses were a bit more concentrated and accelerated than my HS course work required for my HS diploma. So I began focusing on my new major course work and actually was feeling better over controlling my destiny to graduate from college, and planning to pass all transfer courses was my first and primary goal. I had a very experienced older woman as my counselor. She had earned her degree from Stanford after leaving the military of many years. She became a role model for me and she too received a degree in social science as a doctor of psychology from Stanford University. I also had disabled female college professors who had college teaching jobs and I began to wish that when I graduated from college that I could do the same. I believe most of my female professors were also retired, military employees. This too made me see that if I pushed myself hard enough that I too might be able to do the same. I built very high expectations for myself. Unfortunately, after I transferred to the regular university to focus on my upper-division major coursework I began to relapse into some bulimic behaviors. Especially after a test where my score did not reflect how hard I had studied. I would binge secretly in the same place I had studied for my tests. I did not gain weight as at the time I was also using laxatives and my weight did not reflect any signs of binges that occurred frequently in the campus library. I can't believe I actually graduated as passing certain required courses in my major,  was not always easy for me. Thank god I made it through the eye of the needle. My close friends from my community college, a few supportive men I was acquainted with were always around when I least expected them to see me on campus. My friend was an engineering major. I thought he would be way too busy to even take time out of his precious agenda to see me a few times a week when I was not working but studying at the library in the evening. My friend would whisk me away and make me go out to dinner w/ him. not sure why he was obsessing over my nutrition, but it was fun celebrating after studying. He eventually left his career as an engineer and trained as an EMT. He works at conventions as an EMT emergency float. He is married. I am still single. Life w/o a male partner is challenging for me. In my 20's I was never alone I was always going out on dates when Not in the library studying or working at my mall retail job. Life just seemed so much more fun bumming it w/ my male friends from college. Now I work in the jeans dept as CSR. I look at a certain style of jeans and occasionally reminisce back to my old school days from college.It's hard for me to be single. I resent that my x bf broke up after putting so much, time, effort and intimacy, so it seemed, into our relationship. After college graduation, my EMT's best friend was the man I had dated for almost 10 yrs b4 Not getting married but Breaking Up. I am alone now, just me and the scale, and my kitchen full of healthy foods to control my need to use laxatives. They tend to get in the way of working a job such as mine. I can't just go when i need to go, as that saying goes...Thus I am strong, I try not to eat too much, snack less than i used to when using purging behaviors. I miss my favorite brand of sweet snack which i ate at night as I avoided my former boyfriend. I worked overnight answering phones and loved my job. The man I was with seemed jealous of my overnight operator from home job. He was upset as it interfered w/ his needs. When he went out I never made him feel guilty. I stayed home and worked on my phone job, or watched tv on a night off, or went out w/ a BFF.We finally broke up a year after I had graduated from college. I was in the mid of job interviews. This was a very upsetting time for me as I was focusing on becoming hired in The Real World after my college and volunteer jobs were all completed. It was on his terms. Earlier he had acted unstable when I had wanted out of the relationship. He had threatened to kill his self if i left. I had to remain there w/ him until he finally made up his mind about our breaking up for Good.I was just upset because it was at a time where I was really focusing on my post-grad job interviews. I had to save face and left w/o any ?s asked. No groveling or leg-pulling w/ drama and tears about his decision. He had done me a favor FINALLY. As it was his decision I was happy that he wanted to break up. I was just upset that I  was interrupted while going through many local interviews. I wanted to prove to him that college was Not just a waste of my time and efforts. I wanted to show my parents too so they could have been proud of me. I couldn't get the Closure i wished for at the end of our relationship. I was angry, sad, depressed, felt used, dominated, and then discarded. I tried to end my life at that point but had even failed in controlling the end of my life and making a point to everyone that I was exhausted and tired of ALL the damn DRAMA. So I created some of my own DRAMA. I failed to end my life about 20 yrs ago. Then had to move back home and went back to my primary career which I had been doing prior to my grad studies, and all the drama...Now I live here in my own apartment w/ my relative. Life is boring and uneventful, except for when a neighbor croaks downstairs from my apartment and the police come up to question little old me. Is that even right? I'm not sure, and not sure what the officer was thinking of me when he asked of my birthdate for his records. I work hard. I am a good person. I help out in my community as needed. I work hard. I work 2 pt jobs as I never did land an ideal FT job w/ Benefits or anything to run home to mom n dad and brag about. I think I should have been the last neighbor round here to ask questions of, including my birthday. Not sure what the police were thinking of me at the time, but sure didn't feel very respected being chosen to question about the neighbor's death downstairs from my lil apartment. I have just taken my muscle relaxants, pain relievers, otc water pills, and just want to sleep. I still wish at times that I could go to sleep and never awaken to another day of loneliness, and having to work so hard for hardly anything. I miss the old friends or acquaintances whom I believed were my true friends. Funny, most of my girlfriends who seemed so strong, independent, and stable ended up being total strangers later on in life to me. They seem to really depend on the domestic way of life and are nothing like their older, more feminist, stronger former female selves from college. I feel like I haven't changed that much. I am loyal to myself and my values. I remained myself in spite of all the drama I have had to put up with so far in my life. I could ramble on but this is it for now.Good night to all and Make the best of your life as u only have 1 life and 1 chance to appreciate the life given to you. You make your life what u want to make it. Choose Recovery, choose to be healthy, and choose to live...

You can review our community guidelines here. We are also concerned about your safety. If you are in a crisis please text "NEDA" to 741741 for live support from a trained crisis volunteer or you can call  (800)273-TALK(8255). Please stay safe!

column5: My freshman year in college was when my eating disorder really started to take over me. Insecurity and body image issues were always a problem. Before I had went a few months restricting but got myself out of it. This time around I had a clean slate. Without the intention of actually losing weight, I saw college as a chance to get "fit". I wanted to go to the gym and I wanted to eat healthy. Needless to say I lost weight in just three months. Still I had no idea. I knew I got smaller (but how much?) Honestly, I never even weighed myself. It wasn't until my best friend saw me that she bought the possibility that I would have an eating disorder.I'm from Shanghai and in China, eating disorders and mental health do not get the attention that they should. Being raised that way it never occurred to me that I would have one. Anyone will a mental illness seemed so serious, so extreme and I often associated my disordered behaviors as small insecurities that everyone would have. After some time, I began to realize that she was right. I was bound to certain times of eating, certain foods, overworking my body through exercise. I had no energy, no time to see or make new friends. I was more miserable than I've ever been. And so it's taken some time and lots of courage to want to get better. Returning back to Shanghai this summer, I've somehow managed to block out all my disorder thoughts and allowed myself to eat. Because I was restricting for so long, I think I experienced extreme hunger. I would binge and snack and eat late at night, sneak my food, and not be able to stop even when eating brought me to the point of discomfort. This went well for about a month. I never weighed myself because I knew if I did it would break me. I never allowed myself to think about the weight I gained and focused rather on eating and being out, being able to enjoy time with my friends ad family. It wasn't until a few days ago my best friend came to me again. Yes, physically and mentally I seemed better. I was eating. But all I had done was avoid any thoughts related to my eating disorder. She said I should find a counsellor. That, once again, I had convinced myself that I can beat this on my own and that, once again, I will fail. It only took her a day for me to see that she was right. My first day working as an intern I got up, wanted to get changed. All my clothes that at one point fit me, then all of a sudden because oversized, starting to fit again. I did my best to brush this off. An hour later, I was standing in the elevator going up to my office. I saw my reflection in the elevator. Once again, I tried to brush these thoughts off. Later in the day, I went to the bathroom. The bathroom had a full body mirror. That is when i couldn't avoid it anymore. It was staring me right in the face. Every detail that I noticed was all wrong and there was no escaping it. I was ashamed, disgusted, grossed out and all I wanted to do was go home, hide and cry. This was yesterday. I realize although I hope a better future is ahead, right now, the only way for me to feel good about myself is for me to starve and be skinny. Yes I had so many problems when I was smaller. My hair fell out, I was weak, I always felt like fainting, I got almost no sleep and I never got time with my friends. But one thing I never had was the insecurity. That's my biggest fear. Gaining weight and having all those self-deprecating thoughts resurface. And they are beginning to. So I guess I'm lost in my recovery right now. Because as of today I start restricting and I don't even feel bad about it. I just want my body to go back to the way it was. To stop imagining people calling me names behind my back whenever I'm in public.
column9: Dear kellyjliu, we would like to let you know that we edited your post to remove mentions of detailed disordered eating behaviors and weight numbers, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue posting!

column4: Just need to know I'm not alone
column5: This is my first time acknowledging I have a problem.  I struggled with food and eating around people when I was in my teens, and now, a couple of decades later, I am having a similar issue.  About a year and a half ago I began a new sport, which I love, and I compete in regularly.  The problem is this sport is very much dependent on weight, and to make weight, my coach has encouraged me to take measures that are difficult for me to keep under control.  I train several hours a day, and have a very regimented eating routine.  This would be fine, but now, when it is time to celebrate or be with family and friends, I can't eat.  In fact, I struggle to eat at all around anyone unless it is the very specific foods I have decided are "OK."This has really become a problem for me.  I didn't eat at my best friends wedding.  I have begun chewing and spitting.  When we have a team celebration I can't eat, or I pretend to eat so people don't bug me.  My coach has realized it is a problem, and has been encouraging me to eat foods that I enjoy, but I just feel guilt.  The power I feel when I am able to turn down the food I want to eat is so seductive, but then I have very little joy in my life because I can't be around people or attend parties that involve eating.  The other day I decided to eat a cookie, to prove to myself that I would not gain weight from it.  My husband walked in, and I had a panic attack.  I ended up crying uncontrollably.  Over a cookie.  I recognize that the regiment of my training and my overall enjoyment of life requires food, but I'm really struggling to enjoy it.  I am starting to feel very lonely and hopeless.  I want to be happy.Thanks for reading, and for your support.
column9: Hi fannycat! We're sorry to hear that you're struggling, however, we're glad to see you here and hope that the forums provide you with the support you deserve. We would like for you to take a look at our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. column5: Hi everyone, I'm sorry if this has already been asked before but I've only just found this forum and haven't had a chance to read through all the posts yet. So basically I'm 34 years old and I'm above a healthy weight I'm probably classed as over weight if using the BMI thingy but I've been dieting/restricting/binging/purging since I was 9 years old (the bulimia started age 14) I've only just in the last 4 weeks heard of this recovery method so I decided I have to do this now as I have a 2 year old daughter and I wont have her growing up around this disease. So I'm going through extreme hunger right now and I'm wondering is it normal for me to have extreme hunger if I was already "over weight" when I started? I've not seen any posts online from anyone else who is doing this and who has been above normal weight to start with. How long did this part of the journey last for everyone?
column9: Hi Sammie34! We're sorry to hear that you're struggling for so long, however, we're glad to see you here and hope that the forums provide you with the support you deserve. We would like for you to take a look at our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. However, we hope to see you continue to use the forum!

column5: In fewer words than what was said. My parents basically told me if I don’t start going back to the gym then I’m not going back to school in August. They said I am always “tired” because I’m depressed and that I need to start bettering myself or I will be sent to in patient blah blah. What they don’t realIze is the pressure. The pressure to do more, be better. Why can’t I just be me. My whole life I have been moving, and leading and chasing dreams that I knew I probably couldn’t meet but knew that trying to reach them was half the battle. What is wrong with for once in my life wanting to breath, but I am a barreiro and we must be warriors in the name of health. We must not only work more but harder than everyone else. We must not let our insides destroy our outsides. We must smile and be okay because you could be hurting inside but at least everyone around you is happy. So tomorrow I will get up and go to the gym. When I go back to college no one will understand why I’m cold all the time again, or why my joints ache no matter the weather. I’ll just smile and say treatment worked wonders, and this is just the sad cycle of a young girl with an eating disorder.
column9: Hi, charliebarr, we're sorry that you're struggling with these thoughts and feel that your family isn't understanding what you're going through. You mentioned some concerning symptoms and thoughts in your post. We first want to provide you with a list of some signs and symptoms of a medical emergency: The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit If you experience any of these, we highly recommend seeking help from a medical professional as soon as possible. Another option is 911. Also we wanted to provide you with some resources for immediate crisis situations:  Crisis Textline: Text "NEDA" to 741-741 Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 800 273-8255Live chat assistance - http://dialhelp.org/?page_id=7759 or Text 906-356-3337Imalive: 1-800-784-2433 or visit https://www.imalive.org/ Please take care!

column5: For over two years now I have silently struggled with binge eating and bulimia and it has completely taken over my life--binging and purging is all I think about. I have always struggled with my weight growing up, but when I got to college I decided that it was finally time to do something about it. By the time I entered my sophomore year of college I had lost X pounds and I felt on top of the world. I lost that weight by dieting and eating healthy, but eventually the initial excitement of my weight loss went away and I wanted to lose more, but at the same time I missed eating unhealthy food. That's when my binging and purging began. It started out slowly--the occasional cheat meal and then some purging afterward. It didn't seem so bad at first and I started losing weight. I was eventually down X pounds from my original weight at the beginning of college and I was so happy because I finally felt beautiful and confident. I then focused my energy on eating extremely healthy and working out because I didn't feel the need to purge anymore. I didn't purge for almost 6 months because I finally found happiness. I cared so much about what people thought about me and whether or not boys found me attractive so when I was skinny and beautiful, I was content and stopped my bulimic tendencies. In the beginning of 2018, I had a falling out with my best best friend and lost a close family member all at once. My world came crashing down and even though I still had an amazing family and support system, I turned back to food to give me comfort and I fell back into my old bulimic habits. I moved into a new apartment alone, stopped hanging out with my friends, and isolated myself completely from everyone who loved me. I even started getting into drugs which further deteriorated my mental health. I even stopped attending my classes because I would eat whatever I wanted to order/could find and then would purge it all--I did that about X times a day. At first, my body did not change, but over time I started to gain more and more weight, which made me more depressed and binge/purge more. My life continued like this for a while and I became a shell of the once happy and driven person I used to be. A good friend of mine sat me down one day and explained to me how everyone was worried about me and that I needed to change if I wanted to keep my friends because if I kept pushing everyone away, eventually people would stop trying. After that conversation, I started to turn my life around and moved into a new house to get a new start. I started losing weight and eating healthy and became happy again. I stopped binging/purging and turned my focus to rebuilding the friendships I had lost. My life was finally getting better. I started turning my life around at the beginning of 2019 and so far it has been nothing but great. However, I am starting to gain weight again and I have recently started to binge/purge again. It has only been in small amounts--nothing crazy like it used to be but I am so worried about slipping back into that dark place. Nothing specific has happened to make me depressed, but I think the years of suffering from bulimia coupled with the drug use from my past has really taken a toll on my mental health. I have an amazing family, great friends, and an amazing boyfriend, but for some reason the only thing that truly makes me happy is being skinny. I know that is not a healthy mentality, but that is how I feel. I have so many people in my life who love me and support me, but I feel so alone. I have a blessed life and I should be happy, but nothing brings me joy. I don't find happiness in the things that I used to love. Working out used to be my favorite thing in the world and made me so happy, but I can't find the motivation to get back in the groove. I know that if I just force myself to get out of bed and do something active everyday I can find happiness, but I just can't bring myself to do it because I would rather lock myself in my room and binge/purge... The binging and purging only happens when I am alone and/or have too much free time to myself so I decided to get on this forum to see if anyone else can relate to my story. No one in my life understands and I just need help getting out of this rut. I don't want to be in this mental state anymore and I need advice so please, if anyone has any answers about how to break the shackles of binge eating and bulimia, let me know. I understand recovery doesn't happen all at once so I am ready to start taking baby steps because it's time for me to admit I have this problem and figure out a recovery plan. If you have read this far, from the bottom of my heart, thank you so much for your time. Much love.

column4: I don’t know if I have a problem
column5:
Hi,
I don’t know if I actually belong here. I took the screening tool and it said I was at risk. I’ve known for some time my relationship with food has been bad. I do suffer from mild body dysmorphia and find myself worried about my weight frequently. I am not considered underweight and definitely don’t even feel close to being so. My main problem is that I avoid eating and get terrible feelings when I do. Although I show many of the signs I hesitate to say I have a problem because some days I’ll be really happy and feel able to eat.
I’m just wondering if anyone has an experience like me or  has advice for how to tell if it’s a serious problem?
column9: Hello monica52648,  We are glad to hear that you are finding support here on the NEDA forums. A portion of your post was edited and deleted due to the mention of specific numbers that may be triggering to other members of the forum. Our community guidelines are always available to review here: http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines . In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST).

column5: I never thought I had an eating disorder, because the only eating disorders I knew about were anorexia and bulimia. For me personally, I don't worry too much about my weight, however my relationship with eating food in general is very very difficult. I get terrible anxiety just thinking about going out to dinner with acquaintances or even relatives that are not my immediate family. I don't even know how to explain it but something about eating a full meal just makes me worried and I start to feel sick or nauseous so I can never finish a full meal. It used to be a lot worse for me where I would get scared of choking on my food or having an allergic reaction to new foods. I know it is irrational but eventually I just had to start eating more anyways because I was getting so weak and tired all the time. My stomach would hurt so bad and I would get dizzy if I didn't eat. Now, I physically am capable of eating, but before, I literally could not. Now, it's still difficult for me because I get so anxious eating around people. In school, when I have to eat my lunches, I eat painfully slow and always think that someone is watching or judging how I eat. I avoid messy foods because I don't want to embarrass myself in front of people. I get major anxiety just imagining a situation like a first date, where I would have to go get dinner with a guy I like. I just get nauseous because I'm so anxious about these little things and it literally stops me from eating. I'm reading over my blog post right now and it seems so irrational, and the reasoning I'm giving for not wanting to eat because of being embarrassed just sounds so stupid, but for some reason it's just ingrained in my head. Clearly, my disordered eating has something to do with my anxiety because I just overanalyze all situations in my life like eating in social situations. I don't feel like I can talk to my parents or even my friends about it because they will judge me or think I'm weird. Or worse, my parents might get really concerned about me and I don't want to worry them. So, I'm too scared to see a doctor and I don't know what to do at this point. Eating has become a chore for me rather than something you're supposed to indulge and enjoy with other people. I honestly don't know what to do but I want to get better because this disorder is stopping me from spending time with people and growing as a person. I actually love who I am and I think I have a great personality but I get so worried and scared about these things, and at this point I'm used to either eating alone in my room or avoiding food until I can come home and eat by myself. Any advice?
column9: Dear nela2012, we would like to let you know that we edited your post to remove descriptions of disordered eating behaviors, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue posting!

column5: I’ve been struggling with disordered eating in various forms for about 15 years. I am of a healthy weight so I feel like no one believes me that I feel so sick. I am trying to get help however I have no insurance. I finally saved enough money to afford a therapist and a nutritionist, however I recently had to stop going. I had insurance through marketplace For 5 months last year... that I cancelled because it was so bad and I knew I needed help and I couldn’t get it with insurance (ironic I know)... and I recently got a letter from the IRS stating I have to pay back the credit they paid to make insurance more affordable (at the time that I had the insurance my projected income was lower than it ended up being after taking a new job a few months after canceling) so I had to stop treatment.  Right after I stopped I started restricting again. I go through phases of deliberately restricting  and sometimes I don’t even know I’m doing it . I currently feel so exhausted, dizzy, and achy on a daily basis that it is hard for me to function some days. I have been trying to eat normally but it hurts and I feel sick unless I eat the certain things I’m used to. I feel like I’m scared to eat because I don’t know what my tummy is going to do so I restrict more. I get so bloated sometimes that If I’m doing anything with friends I use behaviors I don’t want to be bloated and feel sick. It’s sooo frustrating. I had my hunger cues somewhat normalized for a little bit  and was somewhat able to eat normally and now they are all out of whack and I don’t even get them again I just feel like my battery ran out and then I can’t eat because I feel sick and I have no energy or ambition to make food or get food so I just lay on the floor for hours wondering how much longer i can do this and what damage I’ve caused.I just need some hope or some advice anything. This is so isolating.
column9:
Dear Katdancer, we would like to let you know that we slightly edited your post to remove descriptions of disordered eating behaviors, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding! You also mentioned that you were feeling dizzy. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
Please stay safe!

column5: hi. okay, warning, this is going to be pretty long, i’m really sorry. so, in 14, a female, and i used to be pretty heavily overweight. i hated how i looked and in august of 2018 i started trying to lose weight. at first it was going really good and i lost some weight. but i kept going. i restricted. i lost weight again and i still wasn’t satisfied. so i decided to eat less. i lost more weight which i know isn’t even bad for someone suffering from what i am: i rationalized that i’ve seen people with anorexia or other ED’s who look so much skinnier and even though i wouldn’t admit it, i was jealous of the fact that they were so skinny (which i know is super disrespectful and not ok). my parents were getting worried but i really didn’t think anything was wrong. my mom started crying and talking about how she couldn’t afford to send me to a recovery program but she would if she had to. so i went back up to X calories. since then, i’ve gained some weight, which i hate. i hate how i look. and i think deep down i realize that i’m probably not fat, anytime i get up to do something i look in the mirror and just look at how disgusting i look. recently, i’ve been eating quite a lot, but every single time i eat i hate myself. i know that it’s good that i’m eating, but every time i do all i can think is that i’ll gain back all the weight, and i cannot go back to being fat. i just want to eat like a normal person and be okay with it. if you e read all of that, first off, i’m sorry, and second, if you could offer some advice i would really appreciate it.thank you, Jordan

column4: My menstruation cycle is messed up
column5: So I’ve been restricting (but not too much) and binging on and off for a while now and my period came 3 weeks late. It’s been a month and I’m still on it but it’s very light to the point where it’s more like spotting. I’m trying to get rid of this spotting problem because in two weeks I’m going on a road trip to Florida and there’s gonna be a lot of beaches involved where I have to wear a lot of clothing that shows a lot of skin since it’s gonna be hot and sunny. And tips on what I should do and how to stop my spotting?

column5: No work this evening @ my retail job. Yesterday I felt so exhausted at work that I almost collapsed. I wish I could just go to my local pool a few nights per week and kick it doing a few good laps in the Olympic sized pool. I hate always worrying about my budget and of how many hrs I feel I need to work weekly at both jobs so I can afford to shop online, at the outlets that I adore on my days off from my retail job, or just on healthy foods which I have limited time weekly to run across our very Busy neighborhood street just to p/u basic weekly foods to keep me eating so I don't pass out from fasting for too long. I felt like an airhead at work yesterday. On way to Burlington Outlet I drove up a curb and later my undereye skin was bluish and I felt spacey. So last nights shift seem to go on forever until I came home to take PM meds and crash n burn on my futon here in my lil studio-sized apartment. I emailed my shrink and asked whether we have any new women's support groups for night bingers and fasters like myself. I am waiting for his response...

column4: Delayed Period and I sooo Hate PMS...
column5:
I feel much more bloated than the usual. My throat is so dry. I think this hormone is replicating the effects of pregnancy. I am not pregnant just feel more like a full figured female 40-something lately. I must walk at the mall during my break today. I feel refreshed, i just took a shower and used a new hair detangler and some Moroccan hair oil. I managed to use mom's Italian Thinning shears to thin my super chunky hair out. Then had to hand trim areas around my neck to Not looking like i cut my own hair. I have curly hair and kinky w/o the hair oil too. I have had this surge of energy lately. Hope I can use it for work and at night have been doubling up on meds for a decent nights sleep.  If i didn't work i would forget to eat. I know i sound all mixed up and yes u are probably 100% correct. My life is in limbo and i just feel so insecure currently.
God, please help me get through this day Amen...
column9: Dear chunkymonkey68, we would like to let you know that we edited your post to remove specific disordered eating behaviors and descriptions, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding!

column5: I've had a problem with overeating for a really long time but it has escalated in recent years.When I was still very small, probably at the age of 8, my sister pointed out that I had cellulite. I don't exactly remember what my reaction was but I most likely started to cry. As the youngest in my family, I've always been the sensitive one; I cry extremely easily in front of my family. I simply cannot cry in front of other people though. There have been times where I have tried to force myself (at funerals and such), but I simply have not been able to cry in front of someone outside of my immediate family probably for 10 years. On another occasion, my mom had put a certain kind of food into a bowl and I remember my sister took the bowl to her room. I was in 7th grade then. Later, after she had put it back downstairs, I took the bowl to my room (I sort of felt entitled to do this since my sister had taken it to her room as well) and ate almost all of the food that was inside of it. My sister eventually found out and told my mom. I remember my sister accused me of having no self control when she initially realized what I had done. This automatically made me burst into tears. My mom was quite harsh too. I wouldn't say we had a fight though because I didn't talk back to her, I just sort of sobbed as I listened to her.The first time I clearly recall having negative thoughts about my body was in 6th grade but surely it started before that. In 3rd grade, I was friends with the more spoiled, popular girls in my grade and one day one of them called be fat. Looking back on this, the girl who said this was probably projecting her own insecurities because she wasn't as thin as the other girls in our friend group either. I wasn't really fat, I was just sort of chubby. I can't remember how much it affected me or if it really made me feel insecure though.I think some time around middle school, I was in the car with my mom and my sister and they pointed out how insecure I was about my body. I can't remember what I said that elicited that response but I remember my mom acknowledged that it was partly the fault of her and my sister. I wished they would have done something about this but we never really talked about it again.I have always done some sort of physical activity to try and keep in shape which was mainly my parent's incentive. But that's not to say that I didn't enjoy partaking in these activities. For a long time (almost all of middle school) this for me was swimming. The only time I really think I was skinny was in the summer after 7th grade when I used to go to the pool a certain amount a week. Other than that, I've always considered myself a little bit chubbier than other girls. Then in 9th grade, I started going with my dad and my sister to the gym. The first couple of times I got extremely light-headed because I wasn't really used to this kind of physical effort. I was also really bad at doing any exercise that engaged my abdomen. My sister would call me weak and for the first time, this motivated me to do better, and I became the more determined of the three of us.But my issues with body image started to escalate in 10th grade when I started going to the gym only with my dad (my sister had left to collage). He took me to his own personal trainer who would weigh me on a weekly basis. I want to first acknowledge that it is a privileged to have had access to a personal trainer and that this would have been of great help to be had I been on better terms with my body. But I had never really weighed myself before because at my house we only had an old-fashioned medical scale which I didn't know how to use. He told my I was borderline overweight but I didn't feel like I was overweight and I didn't look like I was overweight and my parent disagreed with him as well. He tried to put me on a certain meal plan which I then gave to my mom. She refused to have me follow it and made my dad tell the trainer to stop trying to make me lose weight. But this really got into my head and that's when I started employing more severe methods to try and lose weight: I would engage in certain eating disorder behaviors. Needless to say, none of this worked as I could only keep it up for about a day.Around this time I also started to engage in other eating disorder behaviors as a way to cope with stress. I am generally more prone to stress than most of my peers. In the past year, I struggled with eczema and psoriasis. My mental health is also not the best and I struggle with seasonal depression due to the passing of three very close members of my family over the last two years. So it was quite natural for me to begin to seek comfort in food. When I would stay up later than my parent to work on and assignment, It was always a given that I would engage in certain eating disorder behaviors. It was usually was food that I found comfort in. But it wasn't really so severe. I wouldn't eat everything in one sitting and I wouldn't eat till I was painfully full. Realistically, I wasn't actually eating because I was stressed, I was eating because I was alone and because I was free of my family's perceived judgement, of course this didn't actually exist. But I have only now began to see this.Then, last summer, I lost a certain amount of weight from July to around October by eating a certain amount of calories every day. I adored how I looked and I was extremely proud of myself. This may have been a result of the fact that when my sister had come home for summer break, my parents praised her for how much weight she had lost. I remember my dad saying something along the lines of "If you put in the work, maybe one day you'll look like your sister," but didn't say this this in a condescending way though, it was meant more as an encouragement. As a result of my drastic weight loss, I lost my period for 5 months. This reaped havoc on my hormones as I was simply trying to speed up the process of puberty. My skin was terrible and my appetite had completely disappeared. There were days in which I would engage in certain eating disorder behaviors all day. Then I staI just want to thank any readers for

column5: I've slipped into anorexia for the first time about 4-5 years ago, but managed to come out of it by myself and regain almost all of my weight after a couple of years. However I only now recognize that I've probably never fully recovered mentally, and as a matter of facts I've relapsed pretty heavily about a year ago. At first I started eliminating all sweet and junk food (I've always had a serious sweet tooth), but after restricting my meals I got into a cycle of not eating much, bingeing the junk food I was restricting, and then skipping meals because of the guilt. I tried to fix this by starting to use a calorie tracker and radically changing my diet, eliminating ALL of the junk food that was triggering my bingeing behaviour and starting to eat only what I considered "healthy" whole foods. Things got out of control pretty fast tho, and I've lost some weight since December now (and I was already underweight at the time), and I'm now completely addicted to calorie counting. Because of this I've contacted an health centre, but my appointment is in two weeks.However, wanting to make the first big step as soon as possible, I've stopped counting calories cold turkey and uninstalled all of my calorie tracker, while at the same time finally giving myself permission to eat whatever I want without trying to restrict and control anything. Thing is, these first few days of freedom I literally find myself obsessing over certain kinds of "forbidden" food that I haven't had in months, and giving into my cravings always ends up in a binge. I feel like I'm never full, never fully satisfied, even if I'm enjoying and savouring every bite I take. Am I doing the right thing or am I developing another kind of eating disorder? I'm scared that this will become a bad habit and that my body won't fix itself overtime but just keep on craving because it got used to it. Should I just take a different approach or just let myself fully go for this couple of weeks?
column9: Hi lovaas, thank you for posting to the forums! We had to slightly edit your post to remove the mention of specific numbers, which may be triggering to other users. The community guidelines relating to that can be found here. We hope you continue to use the forums as a resource!

column5: This is my first attempt at recovery. I have been dealing with binge eating disorder for years now, but I’ve been in denial. I haven’t wanted to admit that I have an actual problem. My life is good on the outside, but inside I’m struggling and I figured an online forum would be a good outlet.I binge eat about once a week. I feel so out of control, and the guilt the next day is unbearable. I had an incident last week. I slept at my mom’s house and we had entirely too much to drink. I blacked out and don’t remember going to bed. I also don’t entirely remember binge eating in the middle of the night. I woke up the next day to my mom saying “don’t eat anymore food!!” She then pointed out everything that I had binge on in the middle of the night. I felt absolutely disgusted and ashamed. I couldn’t even look my mom in the eye. That was the moment that I realized maybe I do actually need help. To punish myself the next day, I ran and restricted. I couldn’t open up to my mom or boyfriend about how seriously this has affected me. And this is certainly not the first time that a binge like this has happened. I can use behaviors multiple times per week. I know that the drinking doesn’t help. I feel extremely out of control when I binge, sober or not. And the shame the next day/immediately afterwards is unbearable. It is truly starting to affect my life.I have never confessed this to anyone. I am hoping this online forum will grant me some sort of support. Hoping somebody on here can over any advice/support! I want to change this habit. :( Thanks for listening.
column9: Dear Livemylife, welcome to NEDA forums! We would like to let you know we edited your post to remove specific mentions of food and eating disorder behaviors, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please keep posting!

column5: Hello, This is my first time expressing myself to a platform like this. I never told the whole story to anyone because I always thought it just doesn't worth it, but ı can't do it anymore. I'm tired of trying and failing so here is my story. Maybe writing it to a forum would help me: I was a happy kid. People were telling me that I'm beautiful and I have a great physique. They were saying that I can do modelling when I grew up. For this reason, I never thought about "gaining weight" or any other thing until I turn into 14. I had the confidence back then and I was the cheerful person in my friend group. Ok, maybe you're going to laugh at this because it is not that serious when ı tell but all my insecurities initiated from a simple thing a girl told me "I thought you were thin but look at your tights". After that, I began to look at the mirror more carefully. Every time İ look at it, I was only seeing a fat girl with big tights, so I stopped eating. I was never the same and yes, as I can remember all those things started from. simple sentence. Then I went to high school. People were still complimenting me but a part of me was never believing. I never said thank you. I began to eat less and less and while I was becoming thinner people were complimenting me more. After some point, I was just telling myself, "you are not smart, you can't sing, you can't dance, you have nothing special except your beauty. If you gain weight and lost those compliments there would be no you." so I gave up eating certain types of food. I was telling people that I became vegetarian for animals but no. ı actually wanted to lose weight. After four years I was still struggling. My parents were always suspicious but we never talked about it. WhenI was 18 (last year) I began to engage in certain eating disorder behaviors. Every time when I came home from school with an empty stomach, I was taking a bunch of certain foods and engaging in eating disorder behaviors. After that ı was hiding the food. I didn't know what to say when my mother noticed it. How could I explain? ı just didn't want to gain weight. Do you know what hurts me the most? She started crying. My parents did nothing wrong. They were really supportive and everything but they thought. it's because of them.Even while I was crying, ı was thinking about how many calories I'm burning meanwhile but I didn't traumatize by anything. Whatever happens to me it really because of me. I couldn't tell people that I have an eating disorder. I was (I am still)  telling them that I have panic attacks due to hormonal disease. I am a liar I know. Now? I keep engaging in certain eating disorder behaviors and I gained a certain amount of weight. People stopped complimenting. I keep myself busy and trying to get better. There are things that I am good a now which is development. If ı stop engaging in certain eating disorder behaviors, EVERYTHİNG İS GOİNG TO BE FİNE.Please help me. Any advice. I'm open for anything. I just want to stop engaging in certain eating disorder behaviors and everything is going to be alright.

column4: Not sure if I am in the right place
column5: Hi all, I am a 33 year old female. I have suffered from a variety of eating disorders since high school. I started purging when I was in junior high, then starving until I was hospitalized in my 20s. Then eating normally and exercising it all off until I was diagnosed with a heart arrhythmia (nothing serious, but not getting proper nutrition does this I guess). And binge eating. Currently I am in the cycle of certain eating disorder behaviors. I am a certain diet but as I am not overweight and hunger does not seem to be something my body understands, it doesn't work for me. I know a diet is the worst thing to do when in recovery but I like rules and I am so out of control when I binge that I feel like i need strict rules. I am so sick of this. I keep wanting to go to a psychologist but I am scared and ashamed. And so tired! My most recent bloodwork suggests I am postmenopausal and I haven't had a normal period in years thanks to my self-abuse and eating disorder roulette, even at a "normal" weight. I gain and lose the a certain amount of weight every month, which is hard on me. I feel like I am destroying myself. Food is all I think about. I literally cannot think about anything else for more than 5 minutes. I am on my last legs here. I really need help.
column9: Hi damagedgoods, welcome to the NEDA forums. We had to slightly edit your post to remove specific diets and behaviors that may be triggering to others. You can view the community guidelines here. Also, we encourage you to contact the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 M-Th from 9am-9pm or Friday from 9am-5pm if you would like assistance in finding other resources. We encourage you to keep posting on the forums for help and support.

column5: I barely know how to begin. I can’t believe I’m here again. I’m 26 years old and i first realized i had an eating disorder when i was about 14. I was obsessed with engaging in certain behaviors and then eventually this led me to have a huge obsession with food. I felt guilty for eating a single meal, which led me to engage in certain behaviors. Eventually i did start engaging in different behaviors because i knew it would help me feel better. I always knew this behavior was straight up crazy because nobody else around me ever felt out of control around food. I never told anybody. I’ve never been over weight because of it technically but I’ve gained plenty of weight over the years and then i would diet hard or even just eat healthy and go back to what felt like a better weight. Anyway, although i have such a history with a certain eating disorder behavior i mostly stopped this cycle a few years ago. I learned how to eat more “carefully” i thought, and i would  often think that this was finally gone. Until one night where my obsessions would creep back in and i would eat anything i could get my hands on that might satisfy my cravings. Within the last year i got better at being on such a good schedule with food and i completed a workout program successfully and my body has been looking pretty great, except for the fact that most nights I engage certain eating disorder behaviors. I keep trying to forgive myself and let it go so i can start fresh but each day i come up with a new crazy way to sabotage myself again. Maybe never fully dealing with this unhealthy fixation on food has just crept back in on me. I have been dealing with a lot and working a ton. It’s just feels like i keep giving up on myself and i truly can’t believe I’m back engaging in these behaviors that i honestly thought i beat. If anyone reads this and can relate or has advice i would appreciate it so much. Thanks

column5:
I let my nutritionist and therapist know that during exercise and normal routine activities I have been getting light headed or dizzy. They said it's serious and needs to be checked out. How serious is this? Is it something that can wait a few days or a week for an appointment?Thank you,
Dawn
column9:
Dear Missyd, you mentioned that you were feeling dizzy. Dizziness is a sign of a medical emergency that requires immediate medical attention. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
We recommend that you seek medical help as soon as possible. Please stay safe.

column4: Help. I’m so tired of this ED
column5: I am 52 years old and I have had an eating disorder since college. I was able to get a handle on it around the time I was 24/25, but it crept in again about 7 years ago and it’s been with me ever since. I’ve tried several times to free myself of this burden I carry every second of every day, but it’s too strong. I overexercise and I want to stop so badly. I’m aware of what I’m doing, but I can’t stop. I have very minimal food during the day, and then I save everything for nighttime. I used to deal with certain eating disorder symptoms, but I went to a nutritionist for eating disorders and now I maintain a certain calorie intake. I eat the same thing every single day because this way I know how many calories I’m eating. Then on Friday and Saturdays I eat whatever I want. I eat more of certain foods and I love every minute of it...until it’s over. Then I feel so guilty and go right back to my restricted ritual on Sunday.  I weigh myself a couple times a day. I want it all to stop. I want to be normal. I want to exercise a normal amount and I want to eat what I want when I want. I hide so many things and I’m tired of it. I’ve been to therapy but clearly I’m not ready to let go because I’m still doing it. I keep saying I’m going to stop but I just don’t know how.

column5: So...I've finally come to terms with the fact that I probably have an eating disorder. No one in my family knows. My friends know. I struggle with certain behaviors a lot. I don't know how to stop. I just, eat whenever I want, then I feel fat and gross and make it all go away. The thing is I am actually clinically overweight. So it's not like I just think I'm fat but I'm not. And the only advice I get is to eat better, but that doesn't help at all. I feel so disgusting most of the time I hate my body. How do you stop purging? Like should I go on a diet, is that safe? What do other people do when they feel full and fat and gross like what are some good ways to not enact in these behaviors?

column5:
I'm Ally. (23)
I've always had issues with my body. My mother was a model, and out of my 5 siblings, I seem to be the only one who isn't underweight naturally. I've had a lot of issues dealing with this growing up and dealt with it by emotional eating. "Luckily" back when I was at school and always enrolled in sports. Once I quit sports, I started gaining weight pretty steadily, to the point where I almost reached (a number I won't mention because I don't want to trigger anyone!) But, there was a drastic difference. Whenever there was a significant change in my body, my family would point it out. "Maybe you should go to the gym." "Maybe you shouldn't eat that" "Maybe you could try losing X pounds so you don't go too far." Or one of the worst comments: "your food stinks! How could you eat that?" from my younger sister who does have model measurements and has always had model measurements. If I asked her to borrow a top or even an oversized sweater she would remind me pretty harshly that we were NOT the same size. I would stretch the clothing or ruin it. This hurt me deeply, and I think this was the beginning of my body dysmorphia, mostly really bad thoughts about myself and sense of self-worth. I stopped shopping for clothing until necessary because I felt like I was a "stretched" out version of the model. I started to feel deeply unattractive and withdrew from the people around me. I still deal with these really dark thoughts. In college, I met my current best friend M, who was suffering from anorexia at the time. She noticed I had a very unhealthy relationship with food but I brushed it off. For some background, I had eating rules to minimize the embarrassment of people seeing me eat. I know this is irrational but I still do this.I reached a breaking point recently. In December of last year, I was at the highest weight I have ever been due to extreme binge eating, and the gym suggestions were coming at me on a daily basis from others. My anxiety keeps me from the gym so I took up another unhealthy habit after seeing a model/influencer try it. I started smoking. The weight dropped, I am ** pounds down. Before last week, it has been only praise from my friends since February and I have felt on cloud 9, but now my paranoia is fixed on my weight number, what foods to avoid for "bloating" and I no longer struggle to use behaviors. Nobody said anything negative about my body anymore. In fact, I had multiple people including my mom ask me for advice, all was good. Until last week, when I hung out at "M"'s house (who has now recovered.. sort of) has expressed concern again. I tried brushing this off as jealousy until her friend told me she has been extensively talking about my recent weight loss and is very concerned, so I started to reflect on my behavior and also realized I had been saying things that are unhealthy. This week has been bad with family problems, and I was so upset that I pretty much used behaviors on Tuesday. Yesterday I did it again until my friend "R", saw me in an oversized t-shirt and jeans that now look pretty baggy. She was really concerned and forced me to eat, her boyfriend was also there so... not the best time lol. I understand she was trying to be supportive but it has made me feeling really embarrassed/ashamed and angry. I spent all night thinking about my body issues, goals, why and how I got here. I wanted to make/join a WhatsApp support group or group chat with people who are recovering if anyone would be interested, or maybe even just a texting buddy who's going through something similar. I'm tired of reaching out/talking to people I know and having them attempt to take control or charge of the situation from an authoritative viewpoint and I'm also tired of using behaviors and feeling so afraid of gaining weight. Would love to find more people on here interested in that extra boost of support too :) If you're not interested in a group chat and have read this entire ramble I've been staring at for over an hour now, then feel free to please give any words of advice or support, I would love to hear if anyone has these anxieties and also does this. I hope I made sense, I sort of rambled for a bit.
