column5: I am a 17 y/o girl in high school. I've been struggling with bulimia and purging anorexia for almost a year now. It began as trying to be healthier and stop being overweight, but it disintegrated into starving and then binging and purging. My family has become involved and I'm enrolled in an outpatient recovery program at my medical provider. I'm being monitored by my parents and I have to sleep in their room at night to prevent any disordered eating. My parents are extremely upset at me for my disordered eating and they keep getting more upset as time goes on. They hold things over my head, like the time they set aside for taking me to appointments or the money they spend on food that I binge/purge. This is after years of shaming me for my eating habits and weight throughout my childhood. They refuse to take blame for my illness and insist that I have chosen to hurt myself on my own accord.I want to recover so badly and live a normal life, but it's so hard to even maintain a few days of normal eating and abstinence without giving in to my self hatred and reliance on food and body image. My daily routine practically revolves around food or using behaviors. My friends are concerned about me and my boyfriend wants me to recover and be healthy. I want to do it for them but I'm scared of gaining weight or losing my coping mechanism for my toxic family and depression.I know that what I'm doing is unhealthy and that I will never be happy with my weight as long as I have an eating disorder. Does anyone have any advice for overcoming my abusive family and healing myself? I'm truly lost right now and I'm losing my will to fight against the illness.
column9: Dear joyquill, we would like to let you know that we edited your post to remove specific eating disorder behaviors, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thank you for your understanding and please continue posting!

column4: my story + scared to ask for doctor's help?
column5:
Please read all the way through, thank you so much.I've always thought I was fat.
I was an extremely skinny child (which I can now see, looking back at photos). But since I was 10 or 11, I've always looked in the mirror and seen myself as fat. My parents laughed when they found out I thought that, because I was so thin, it almost looked unhealthy. In reality, I ate a lot of food and loved it, I was just very athletic.I've always had a huge appetite. I remember eating lunch at school when I was 12, and seeing my friends with smaller appetites barely eat a thing. I wondered why I couldn't have the same self control they had. That same year, a boy commented that my butt looked big in skinny jeans. This stuck with me for YEARS until I realized that a big butt was something desirable in society. Nevertheless, to me, it only confirmed what I already thought in my head: I was fat.When I started going through puberty, I perceived my totally normal weight gain as a sign that I needed to go on a diet. It's so sick that my mind was already so skewed, to even think that gaining weight to accommodate for the fact that I was also growing a lot taller was abnormal. The diets never worked. I was extremely active and loved food, I couldn't eat less. I always ate more than other people. I think this is pretty normal for an active, growing teenager. But as I grew, this appetite never left me.In my first year of high school, I ate all the food my brother got at a party. My parents had it hidden somewhere. This was the first time I remember being shamed for eating something. Partly because it was my brother's, and partly because it was a lot. From then on, whenever I ate a lot of something, or food would go missing, my family would shame me. I understand. They thought it was disrespectful. They bought this food for everyone, and they bought it to use as ingredients in dinner, and I was just eating it all. But, 3 years later, and these voices of shame and guilt have become the ED voice in my head. At the end of grade 9, I had to be in a bathing suit for an event. I thought I was unfit. I desperately wanted abs. I tried to eat better, and exercise more, but I still couldn't control my eating. Keep in mind that at this time, I was still growing, and was still very thin. Grade 10 flipped my life upside down. I continued to gain weight (still was slim), as I was still growing taller. It started to fill out in places like my butt. At the beginning of that year, I started to get attention from guys because of my body. In grade 9, I had been shy, awkward, and unwanted. Now, I had a desirable feature, and I was made to think this was the only good thing I had going for me. I was harassed by boys I considered friends. It really messed me up. For a long time, I was simultaneously disgusted and flattered by their behavior. Even my friends didn't help. Sometimes I would go overboard on eating. I still had a big appetite, and only mild binging tendencies, but no ED behaviors yet. I was still happy as could be, a little insecure sometimes, but I didn't obsess about food and weight. I didn't have a clue what a calorie was and what they meant.I vividly remember something I said to a friend that year that really showcases how an ED was starting..."I feel like I could eat this food right now and I'd still be hungry." It's so painful looking back at that. I wish I could hug the girl I was 2 years ago. She had such an insatiable hunger within her, likely caused by insecurities and loneliness. That's how I interpret this quote, anyways.Going into grade 11, I gained enough weight to start looking a little less like my usual self. This is the first time I remember eating weird combinations of food in large amounts when I was stressed, bored, and/or alone. I hardly noticed. It's sad, because I didn't really want to. I just thought...someone likes some part of me, so may as well go to them and feel less lonely, right?Over the course of that year, I got to my highest weight ever, and was looking unhealthy. I was still doing my sports, but they were more difficult. Sometime in that year, the shame after eating started. I realized how much weight I had gained and I was embarrassed that people had to look at me this way. Family members made comments. I tried to diet and lose weight, and that just caused more self hatred when I binged.The summer after grade 11 began, and I was doing a 4 week camp for my sport. I was still using eating disorder behaviors, but I still rapidly lost weight and muscle. I knew I had a problem at this point, but my happiness from the weight loss overshadowed my concerns.
I got compliments from family members. Some mothers of the girls I play sports with said "you're so skinny now!" They thought they were being nice, but this was toxic. Grade 12 (this year) started, and I was terrified of gaining weight, and of subsequently disappointing myself and others (including my family, and those moms who made the comments).This is when everything took a turn for the worst. Since September, I have felt suffocated and trapped. Every moment of my day is spent thinking about food and weight. What should I eat next? How can I eat the lowest calories possible? Have I gained weight? I can;t go a day without thinking about the weight of myself and others. I cried after I ate and my stomach felt extremely full, most times after a binge. My binges this year have been so bad, I have not even been able to walk afterwards. I just lie in my bed and cry. I despise myself so much. I constantly would take pictures of myself all year and compare them to pictures from the summer to see how much I gained. I have been so consumed by this, I can barely focus in school. I don't want to go to social events or hang out with my friends, I lie in my bed and cry before I go, if at all. I put a blanket over my mirror because I get depressed when I see myself. Now, it's a month away from prom and I'm trying to use eating disorder behaviors, but I still binged today. I haven't gained everything back, but in my mind, I may as well have.
I was in a really dark place in March, and tried disordered eating behaviors, but it hardly worked. So I'm just stuck with all this weight I've gained.
My family refuses to acknowledge this, probably because I'm at a healthy weight. They still call me a rat and a pig if food goes missing.I'm going to the doctor for a physical soon, and I think I may need help. I want to tell my dr everything I said here, but I'm afraid. She's a no nonsense type of doctor, and often dismisses health concerns. As well, I'm afraid I won't be taken seriously because:-I am at a healthy weight
-She will think I am just an unhealthy eater, and need to learn how to eat better because I don't know how
-My parents don't take it seriously, so why would my doctor (granted, I haven't told my parents absolutely everything I've written here, particularly the mental struggles)
-I'll be treated, and not be allowed to lose weight in the process. I hate the weight I'm at right now, it's not comfortable at all.Any help is greatly appreciated :)
column9: Dear icanandiwill33, we would like to let you know that we edited your post to remove detailed descpriptions of sexual harassment and mentions of specific food, which is not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. We are very sorry to hear that you went through such an experience. Our forums are for eating disorders only but you can contact RAINN to get help for those issues. Thanks for your understanding and please continue posting!

column4: How do I need to approach eating when starting my recovery?
column5: My ED is anorexia nervosa...I just got a complete checkup from the doc and everything checked out fine. I'm male. I do not currently have the help of a dietitian although am currently trying to get that squared away. For now, I'm trying to get started on my own until that comes together.I'm not sure what the healthiest approach is however when trying to gain weight. Do I count calories and aim for a certain number? Not count and just eat a certain amount of times per day?How did you guys approach this when starting your recovery?
column9: Dear Marksmith0087, we would like to let you know that we slightly edited your post to remove weight and height numbers, which are not allowed on the forums. You can read our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue posting!

column4: Do I even need recovery or just counseling?
column5: I have been struggling with this problem for the past month and it’s been affecting my mental health a lot. For a large part of my life I had been overweight and dealt with body image issues beginning middle school, but I lost a lot of weight going into high school and I became really thin. I maintained that weight for the first 2 school years until I met the love of my life during my 11th grade year, and that’s when all the weight gain began, due to the endless amount of weekend dinner dates and indulgences. But as they say, the honeymoon phase goes away and along with that, went my distraction from my body. I had a physical check up at that time and my doctor informed me my BMI was higher than what was healthy and I didn’t worry much.. After all I was taking boxing classes a few times a week. My boyfriend has his senior prom this year and since he’s taking me, I wanted to look “perfect” and decided that I needed to lose a lot of weight.. That’s what kickstarted everything. At first I attempted a “healthy” route at losing weight by just eating more nutritional whole foods but that quickly turned into heavy restriction and having safe foods I would eat every day. safe food every day along with intense workouts really depleted me. I was terrified of eating out and had to count every single calorie going into my body, which wasn’t much... This turned into a binge/purge/restrict cycle and I was miserable.. lost my period, my happiness, my sex drive, hunger cues, etc. This went on for about 3 months until I decided I was going to get better and not be scared of food so I began upping my calorie intake little by little while still losing a lot of weight. Still obsessively counting calories, exercising but I was eating a lot more than before. I eventually got to the point where I was eating more. My doctor gave me supplements and my metabolism slowly got better and I got my period back (i’ve had it twice since then). My question and genuine concern is.. I didn’t recover on the minimum calorie guidelines but I feel nutritionally restored at this point BUT my hair continues to fall out and my nails are super thin still, and of course I restrict still but not as much. I stopped counting calories a couple weeks ago, began eating whenever I felt I needed to and I have gained some noticeable weight back on these lower calories.. My mental state is at my worst currently, I’m terrified of gaining all that weight back and I have had disgusting thoughts about myself. Do I need recovery, or just counseling? I don’t want to eat more than I need to and end up overweight again..
column9: Dear equillibrium, we would like to let you know that we edited your post to remove numbers for calories as well as specific details about food intake, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue posting!

column4: From Lovato_ - Concerned about my habits/behavior
column5: Hello, I am not sure if this is place for my concerns but after reading some of the other comments I figured it was worth some discussion. I am also not sure if I am developing an eating disorder, and although I understand no one here is a doctor I figured I would reach out for some opinions before talking with my own doctor about these issues I've been dealing with. Some background info about myself is that I have been diagnosed with GAD, BP II, PTSD, and have not yet had BPD ruled out. I am 24 years old, and have been overweight for almost all of my life with brief periods of consistent and healthy exercise, and have been consuming a vegan diet.. About two months ago, after a long period of no activity, I was at my heaviest. After a yearly check up with my primary physician, my blood work showed that my cholesterol was higher than ever, and my liver enzymes were being affected in an unhealthy way. This to me was my final wake up call to make a change in my life, and ever since I have been on a spiral of obsession. In an effort to lose weight fast I began to work out vigorously every day. Weight began to slowly come off, but no matter how much I lost in one week it never felt like enough. I've started consuming a certain amount of calories every day and this was working for me, but I'm worried about the long term affects it will have on my relationship with food and my overall health. It has taken a toll on my relationship at home and with friends because I am constantly worried about ingredients in meals being prepared for me that I have just found myself eating separately from everyone else when I can. I always make sure that I am getting enough essential nutrients, but it seems that more often than not I am finding myself eating less and less to lose the weight. I have started pre planning meals days in advance and if I know that one day will be more dense than another, I find myself restricting. I know that this behavior is dangerous but I can't find myself stopping. Every time the number on the scale goes down, my mind sees it as progress and I become extremely fixated to keep going. With stress from graduate school and the addition of food obsession and worry, my anxiety has been the worst it's ever been, so much that I have started to concern myself with other health issues in my body that I worry my eating habits may have affected such as my heart and brain. It has gotten so bad that I have had trips to the emergency room in fear that something is wrong with my heart. Long story short, I am worried that I am developing eating disorder behaviors, if I have always had them, or if this is mania for me. I will be talking to my doctor about these issues, but wanted to express my concerns with a community that may understand how I'm feeling, even if it's just for a brief moment.
column9: Here are some signs and symptoms to keep an eye out for Lovato_: The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit Or any other serious medical concernsIf you experience anything on this list, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911.

column5: Hello everyone, First I want to say how truly grateful I am to these forums. I really appreciate how everyone here is so supportive and offers such excellent advice and insights. This is so valuable for people like me who are in the very early stages of understanding the ED and how it has had power over me for much longer than I have realized. I am trying very hard to go against the ED voice, but I am finding that I cannot deny it for more than a day or two at a time. After I eat, I feel extremely guilty and go back to restricting and counting calories. Eating makes me feel like I have lost control and like I have failed at something. And as much as I hate to admit it, eating does make me fear that I will not only gain weight, but become fat. I now understand that these things are part of the ED and that many others who fight EDs have these very same thoughts, fears, and behaviors. These feelings are what make it so hard for me to sustain regular eating. I am wondering how one even begins to go against these fears and feelings? How can I begin to see eating as something healthy and purposeful and not some shameful practice that I need to abstain from?  Thank you again for everything so far. I deeply appreciate everyone here <3
column9: Hi, iwanttolive, since you had mentioned self harm we just wanted to provide you with some resources in case you need them in the future: Crisis Textline: Text "NEDA" to 741-741 or www.crisistextline.orgS.A.F.E: (800) 366 - 8288 or selfinjury.com Please take care.

column5: I have not been formally diagnosed with an eating disorder, but I think I have one. Throughout my whole life I've struggled with my appetite. It's been extremely bad these past few months. I always feel nauseous when I wake up, and I find it difficult to eat certain meals. When I do eat, it leads to me experiencing ED symptoms and behaviors. I seem to have lost the ability to feel hungry. I don't know what to do.
column9: Hi jarussell, thank you for posting, we welcome you to the NEDA forums. We just wanted to let you know that we had to slightly edit your post due to the mention of specific behaviors, which may be triggering to others. For more information about the community guidelines,please visit https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. We encourage you to keep posting and using the forum to find support! The NEDA helpline is also another useful tool for finding assistance. Give them a call at 800.931.2237 or chat with them online (http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/helplinechat) M-TH 9-9 EST and F 9-5 EST. I hope you find the support you are looking for!

column5: I am 17 years old and recently food has become an obsession. When I'm not eating I want to be and when I am eating I hate myself. I've been restricting calorie intake so much that I've dropped weight in the past two months. It would be more to be honest but every few days I will stop restricting  because I'm so hungry and craving everything and I binge eat. I don't know what to do anymore, and I think part of the problem is that since I've lost weight I've gotten so much positive reinforcement from my friends and family. My mom makes comments about it and is so happy because she's always tried to get me to drop weight. But now I'm stuck in this cycle and weighing myself constantly and even my boss had to talk to me to tell me that I have been spacing at work and not being a very good employee and she doesn't know why. I have headaches and am dizzy and irritable. But I don't know how to say anything when my mom is so proud of me and the number on the scale is dropping because when that number drops I feel accomplished. But as soon as that number goes up I'm back to misery. I'm just not happy and I'm not sure what to do. If anyone has any advice I would appreciate it. Thanks for listening.
column9:
Dear moranam, welcome to the forums! We would like to inform you that we slightly edited your post to remove weight numbers, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review the community guidelines here. You also mentioned that you were feeling dizzy. Dizziness is a sign of a medical emergency that requires immediate medical attention. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
Please stay safe and continue posting!

column4: I am conflicted / trying to get better
column5:
I don't know how to start this post or know what questions to ask.  I was recently diagnosed with Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting Type.  Part of me is in shock, another part is in denial.  I am also conflicted about getting help and recovering from this.  I feel that I have a logical side of me that is saying you need to eat more and take better care of yourself.  Then there is another side of me that is instilling guilt after I eat anything.  It is a constant battle, every single day.  I have friends that really don't understand what is going on.  They yell at me to "Just Eat" as if it is something I can do on a whim.My psychiatrist told me I must eat a minimum of calories a day (I am omitting numbers since I know it is not allowed). When she said the number, my immediate reaction was panic and defensive.  I told her F* NO.  After the appointment, I was mad at myself for reactivating the way I did.A month went by and I had my follow-up appointment.  She took my weight to see how much change occurred.  I asked her to not tell me as I have been avoiding scales like the plague.  I didn’t realize the information would be included in my after visit summary.  It showed quite a bit of loss vs a month prior.  I was filled with joy that it went down.  It is like a deep part of me is happy that I am losing weight, it also doesn’t seem to care how I achieve this.  I feel that I’d rather be dead than fat and ugly.I am proud of myself when I go so long without eating anything.  It is like a challenge I give myself, to see how long I can hold out.  When I do eat, I feel like a failure.  I say to myself over and over, you are being bad Catherine.I often watch stories about others who have struggled with this.  I look at their lowest weight as a goal to achieve rather than something to avoid.  Seeing them recover by being forced to eat or a NG tube gives me panic.Part of why I am posting this, it has gotten to a point where my work is being affected.  I am forgetting things; I feel weak and almost lose focus when driving to and from work.  But I also feel like I can’t do anything to help myself.  I work 5 days a week and don’t have time nor the money to go to a in-patent care or hospital.I am sorry that this all seems out of whack and just a bunch of random thoughts.  I have been trying to understand how I got to this point and push myself to get better.Thanks,
Catherine
column9:
Dear Catherine,You mentioned that you feel weak and lose focus. These are signs of a medical emergency that requires immediate medical attention. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
Please stay safe and do not hesitate to contact the NEDA Helpline if you need help with treatment and support options!

column5: Hi everyone! I am new here, and am not quite sure where to start. I have a history of eating disorders in my family. Both my parents had/have eating disorders, my extended family have eating disorders, and so on. I have always grown up around people who either eat way too much to stuff emotions or question every food decision you make, saying "are you sure you want to eat that?" I struggled with weight in high school. This was not due to any particular problem, just that my curves grew before I did: I grew out then up. Last summer, I went into therapy for severe OCD. This OCD didn't bleed over into my eating habits, though. I guess I have always been afraid of that. But here I am now, almost a year later. My OCD is manageable, but my eating habits are out of control. I am into weightlifting and love working out. I have a healthy relationship with the gym. One of my family members had exercise bulimia, so I make sure to not get to that point. But my eating is out of control. My cravings are absolutely wild and I give into them, I cannot resist them. When I have nothing to do, I eat. Not to fill any holes in my life, not to stuff emotions, I just can't stop thinking about food. I eat when I am not hungry, I obsess over some type of food, and I cannot stop. I want to stop. But, I don't know how. Where do I start? How do I stop these twisted cravings and thoughts and feelings of guilt after eating anything. I feel like a different person when I reach for food, I feel like I am lusting after it instead of using it to feed and fuel my body and my brain. Please help. I don't know where to start.
column9: Dear gg_77, welcome to the NEDA forums! We would like to let you know that we slightly edited your post to remove specific mention of food, which is not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelinesPlease continue posting!

column5: I don't know if I really technically have an eating disorder, but I guess my relationship with eating/food isn't the best. Lately I've been calorie restricting, which I've done before, but then every few days I will like buy food and eat half of it in one sitting. Then I guess I just purge, without really meaning to? Or I guess I kind of want to, but I don't even have to make myself force to start if that makes sense? This has happened after each time I've eaten for the past 2 days and I wasn't sure if I should be concerned? I'm at a healthy weight and bmi, but the lack of control in the situation is a little unnerving. And it's honestly gross. But worst of all I usually get this glad feeling when it starts, like now even my body is making it easy for me to not eat/purge? Has this happened to anyone else? Will it stop? I don't even know if this the right forum to be asking this question, I'm so sorry if it's not!
column9: Dear JJChambers12, welcome to the forums! We would like to inform you that we slightly edited your post to remove language about specific eating disorder behaviors, which is not allowed on the forums. You can read more about our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue posting!

column5:
Hi,
After overcoming anorexia I was on my road to recovery when I began to chew and spit, it has now become and everyday occurrence  where I go and buy a certain food and then spit it all out or as much as I can, I have gained all my weight back which doesn't help the sensation. I try to quit everyday but can't seem to stop. I have tried therapy and different apps but still find myself doing it. Has anyone ever experienced this or know how to make it stop. I just want my life back and not think about food and my next binge all the time. I have trouble getting my school work done because I am preoccupied
column9: Hi justtryingtofin...,We are glad to hear that you are finding support here on the NEDA forums. A portion of your post was edited and deleted due to the mention of specific foods that may be triggering to other members of the forum. Our community guidelines are always available to review here: http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines . In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST).

column5: So, I have been doing OP for anorexia for a little under 2 years. I have gained weight, and it has been stable for a while. But the ED thoughts are still there. Lately I have bee restricting and have wanted to loose weight again. My dietician told me that a higher level of treatment would be helpful for me, but she is still willing to do OP with me if I am able to follow through with it. The thing is I do not know if I will. I do not have any motivation for recovery. I am terrified of gaining weight and that is exactly what they will make me do at a higher level. But I am tired of feeling worthless all the time. I have a therapist and a psychiatrist as well, but I still feel anxious and depressed a lot of the time. I just do not know what to do. I know a higher level might be helpful for the emotional aspect, but I DO NOT want to gain weight.
column9: Dear meerkat123, We are concerned about what you have written. You said that you were “feeling worthless all the time.” Even though we don’t know you personally here on the NEDA online community forums, we care about what happens to you. We understand you are feeling hopeless right now and we all feel that way sometimes. However, help is available and people do go through dark times. We want to ask you to call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK. Compassionate, trained volunteers can talk with you about how you are feeling and help you find a way to stay safe so that you can get the help you need to feel better.

column4: Trying to Start Recovery But Can't Find Help
column5: Hello everyone, I am a 30-something female with an eating disorder. I have been trying to get help, but can't seem to find any. My family doctor is unable to refer me for mental health care, I suspect because I live in a rural area and we just do not have those kinds of resources out here. I have called numerous counselors, therapists, ect., both within my area and up to two hours driving distance and have been told either they don't accept my insurance, are not accepting new patients, or they do not treat adults. I have also left several messages with no call backs. Many times no one even picks up the phone to begin with. I have also tried to utilize NEDAs services to get help with finding help, but out of the three contacts they gave, one is not accepting new patients, and the other two simply haven't responded.  I realized in the fall that I needed help and have been trying off and on since then to get it. Without going into too much detail, I am getting to the point where my physical health is being affected by this. I have tried to increase my intake on my own, but I just cannot seem to maintain healthy eating for more than a couple days at a time. I always start restricting and counting calories again. I am locked in this frustrating cycle and I really want to escape it. I have about a year left of graduate school and have ambitious goals for both my life and my career and I know I will not be able to achieve them if this problem with my eating continues. Does anyone know of some other things I can do to help myself until I can find professional help? I am fighting as hard as I can on my own, but as I have mentioned, I always end up sliding back into bad habits. Thank you in advance for your suggestions and insights.
column9: Dear tiff0089, welcome to the NEDA forums! We are sorry to hear that you are having difficulty finding a therapist who specializes in eating disorders in your area. Please do not hesitate to contact the NEDA Helpline again for treatment options and other support resources in your area. The number is 800-931-2237, you can also chat online. Please continue posting!

column5:
My name Is Jenny, I have struggled with an eating disorder since I was 15, I am 23 now.
About a year and a half ago I came to the realization that I truly did have an eating disorder- I had denied it for so so very long. One day, as I was walking across my college campus I found myself winded, nauseas, and wanting to use behaviors because my body was in such bad shape. I had no energy, yet I thought I looked amazing. I just wanted to be as beautiful as the girls around me, the models in the media.. One day while at school I had eaten lunch, but I just could not stand the feeling of being full- being full must mean my stomach was protruding and I was getting fat. I quietly made my way to the most discreet bathroom on campus and used behaviors. Then, I passed out on the toilet and remained there for at least 5 minutes. When I came to I picked myself up and carried on as if nothing had happened. Looking back, I looked so very sickly, but I thought I looked beautiful. I am a Christian and I remember sitting on the bathroom floor of my college and thinking... "Oh my gosh... I am killing myself". My mother-in-law worked on the campus and everything in me was pushing me to just tell her, but I was terrified. One day, I was studying in the library and I could hardly keep my head up, I could not focus, and I felt like I was withering away, so I made the choice in my head that the next time I saw my mother-in-law I would tell her and ask for help- something I had NEVER done, never told anyone. As I was walking out of the library to head to my next class, there she was. I am not sure how I obtained the strength.. but I walked up to her and told her to sit down and I needed to tell her something. I told her I needed help. She looked at me very confused and the next words out of my mouth were, "I need help, mom. I think I have an eating disorder". Tears filled her eyes and she said, "Oh my.. just, not eating? or purging?", it took all of the strength I had to muster the words.. "both" as I held my head down in shame. She said, "Oh dear." and immediately embraced me, in the middle of the coffee shop that led into the library. Right after I finally made the decision to tell her, somehow she was right there and I knew if I did not tell her then, I never would. She kindly walked me to the campus counseling center and sat with me as I filled out my intake. My amazing school counselor cleared her entire schedule and invited me into her office as I held my head low balling in embarrassment, shame, and fear. And thus began the start of my road to recovery. I could tell you I have been successful in my journey the entire time, but that would be a lie. I knew my cycle, I had been in it for over 7 years. For a while I was doing amazing, I had stopped purging and slowly introducing small portions of food into my tiny and shrunken stomach. I was doing so so very well. But that did not last long. I lied to my counselor and told her I was doing fine and eating without purging... but I was still purging here and there. I go through a cycle, I go for weeks, sometimes months of eating and not purging, but then I would feel like I was over eating and becoming huge- my body dysmorphia would take over. I wish I knew what I really looked like rather than what the mirror showed me. Lately, I had been doing so well, eating and feeling so great about myself. But I relapsed. I have been purging lately and I am so ashamed. The journey to recovery is such a hard one, and I wish I could fix it all at once, but I know it is a gradual process. Why can’t I see what I really look like? I want to overcome this. I have such a strong will to beat this… but it looms over me every moment of every day. I feel lost, hopeless, and I am afraid that I am slowly killing myself. When will this ever end?
column9:
Dear JenFos, welcome to the forums! We would like to let you know that we edited portions of your post to remove mentions of disordered eating behaviors and weight numbers, which are not allowed on the forums. You can review our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines You also mentioned that you passed out, which is a sign of a medical emergency. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
 Please be safe!

column4: Scared that I'm developing binge eating disorder?
column5: Hey guys, this might be a long post.I was diagnosed and went into IOP treatment for anorexia when I was sixteen and a sophomore in high school, and continued going to therapy and doctors appointments at that same treatment center for about a year after that. Once I was about a senior, my mom decided I could stop going to therapy because she felt like I had improved. She was still prepping my meals and whatnot, and monitored my weight and what I was eating pretty closely. My mental state was pretty terrible, I felt extremely uncomfortable with the weight gain.I gradually think I lost a few pounds naturally here and there as I entered my freshman year of college, as my mom and I had started going on walks again, (we used to do this during the eating disorder but stopped once I entered treatment) and I wasn't eating as strictly as I had been. I was on the lower end of a healthy weight for my height, and the weight loss wasn't really intentional. I got my first boyfriend my freshman year of college, and he ended up cheating on me in the summer. I kind of spiraled, and lost a bit more weight. I am now a sophomore in college and I at some points this year I have been at or near the same weight I was when I went into treatment the first time. However, I went through January deciding I wanted to just gain a few pounds and not have such a rigid schedule with food- I was tired of food controlling my life, so I decided to try and eat a bit more. I'm not sure if extreme hunger is a real phenomenon, but that entire month was sort of spent overeating (possibly binging?) and my mom took notice and confronted me. She thought I needed to see a therapist.I don't necessarily feel out of control when I'm eating, but I feel like I need to make the most of the times I slip up because I'm not going to let myself eat that food again very often. Most of the time I also feel hungry. I know the solution to this would just be to work on intuitive eating and fixing my relationship with food, but I have a routine of foods I like to eat.So I've been seeing my therapist, and I went back to watching my food intake for the last three months because I want to get back to a lower weight and I feel embarrassed about my mom catching me eating so much. I haven't brought up the eating disorder issues with the therapist even though I know I should, because I'm afraid of change. Right now I feel like I can go back to the anorexia whenever I want and I don't want that control taken away.The past week I feel like I've started to overeat again, and I don't know why. I'm afraid I'm developing binge eating disorder. Could that be it, or is my body just craving the things I have been restricting from it for three years? Ever since I stopped going to the treatment center I have eaten pretty clean, I still avoid a lot of foods. I tend to eat the same things every day and I never let myself have treats.I don't know what to do. I feel like food controls my entire life, and it's all I think about every day. I just turned twenty one, and I feel like I'm still caught up with issues other girls my age have gotten over because I'm still obsessed with being skinny, and I only like myself when I'm a certain weight.I know the logical answer would be to open up to my therapist and get help, but I just want to keep the illusion of the control of choices I have. I know anorexia is controlling me though.
column9: Dear nikittyy, welcome to the forums! We would like to let you know that we slightly edited your post to remove mentions of specific food, which in not allowed on NEDA forums. You can review our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelinesPlease keep posting!

column5: Hi, I'm a college student and I just joined probably about 5 minutes ago. Ever since I've been young, I have struggled with my weight and eating habits. I'm not entirely sure if I have an eating disorder, but I know that my weight and diet affect me mentally and I get very depressed about it. I am a figure skater, and I feel like much of my experience has derived from being in this sport. I feel like I have developed a mindset where my weight and looks define who I am and what I do. I have gained weight while being in college, because I don't have my mom or someone around to criticize what I eat. However, I do have the tendency to be conscious about how much I eat when I am around people, so when I am in my dorm, I binge on a lot of snacks when my roommates leave. I've had a tendency to binge any time my family, boyfriend, friends, or people aren't around since I was in middle school. It feels like a pattern that I can't get myself out of. Every week I have some epiphany that some new diet or attempt to work out is going to change the way I feel, but it never follows through. I'm running out of options, and when I have tried to talk to my friends/family, they think I'm being over dramatic and that I don't know how to control myself. I just wish they understood the severity of how it makes me feel. I'm alone a lot in college, so it makes me even sadder to deal with this. I just want to be happy and healthy. I'm afraid if I continue like this, I'll run into serious health problems or continue until I'm obese. I'm so ashamed of my body, that I don't like going to the gym or wearing certain clothes because I don't want people to look at me in a negative way. I really need help in trying to correct my habits, but I don't feel ready to confront my family or therapist.
column9: Hi bnyanez,  Welcome to the forums! We're so glad you found us, and you've come to the right place to find support and encouragement from people who have been there.  Just so you're aware, your post has been edited slightly to remove the mention of weight-related numbers that may be triggering to other users.  You can view our full community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines Thank you!

column5: This may sound like a silly question, but I don't know if I am bulimic or not.  I have a poor relationship with food and a tendency to binge (which I am trying to address with mealtime routines etc). I don't actively make myself sick, but I use symptoms after most meals. Is it possible to have a psycholigical version of bulimia? Could it be my mind making me vomit or should I be looking elsewhere for a physical explanation for the vomiting? I have had extensive investigations (endoscopy, MRI & CAT scans etc) which have failed to find any physical cause for the vomiting so I am wondering is it possible to have a passive version of bulimia and that I am subconsciously making myself sick just from my mind?

column5:
Hi,
I don’t usually do this sort of thing and am really out of my comfort zone, but I’ve had a particularly bad time relating to my bulimia and am struggling. I was only officially diagnosed a few weeks ago however I’ve been suffering for nearly 5 years. Following my doctor telling me I had bulimia he booked me in for blood tests to make sure everything was ok. I was meant to have these done today unfortunately while having them done passed out due to stress and not eating this morning. Since being on my own this evening I have really worked myself up and so worried about everything to do with what’s happening to my body and my next blood tests. I haven’t told anyone I’m bulimic, which probably doesn’t help. I just don’t feel comfortable to tell my family yet, but I’m at a point where I’m really struggling and would appreciate any advice at all. Thank you
column9:
Dear _kate_, welcome to the forums! We are concerned since you mentioned that you passed out. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
If you are experiencing any of these, we recommend that you seek medical attention as soon as possible.

column5:
Hi I'm Blue,
I'm 21 and I've been struggling with bulimia and binge eating disorder on-and-off for almost 2 years now. Binge eating disorder has had a lot of impact on my social life, my weight and even on my education. I've been in a cycle of doing well, eating according to my meal plan for 1-2 weeks and then relapsing and having to master up the courage and strength to start recovery all over again.
It occurs to me frequently how nice and somewhat comforting it would be to buddy up with someone who's facing similar struggles to mine. We could communicate to encourage and support each other during the good and bad times of recovery.
Let me know if you'd like to chat, I would love to hear from you.
Take care,
Blue

You can review our guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. We hope you find the support you need on our forums. Please keep posting!

column5: Hi - I would like some tips from fellow ED people.  As a background: I have a long history of anxiety and recovered from depression, and along with that in the past two years I picked up habits of binging and purging, which got especially exacerbated last year along with my anxiety and depression to the point where I feared for Thanksgiving and begged my parents not to make me go with them to our family gathering because I didn't want to eat because I knew I would want to purge. At this point, which was just last Thanksgiving, I had a sort of "come to Jesus" moment when I realized I would be graduating college in a few months and I really wanted to terminate the binge/purge cycle. That December I did really well when I got home after finals because I was in the comfort of my own home and my mom helped me with keeping healthier snacks in the house and cooking a lot of my meals, along with myself being able to put my full focus into noticing when I was or wasn't hungry. I try to avoid the scale, but I definitely noticed and felt a lot better about myself with how I looked and felt with just 5 weeks of winter break as soon as I dropped the purges and watched what I ate.  As soon as I got back to school, I got out of track with not eating as healthy and eating a lot on the weekends, and even though I would get uncomfortable with all that I was eating, I never got too out of control or purged and I was able to remind myself that I was doing way better than before break. After Spring Break however, I took steps backwards with my urges to eat - I've been binging daily, eating often very mindlessly and excessively. Basically whatever I could get my hands on at every point of the day. I've gotten to the point currently where I eat just because I see something in my vision. I will feel extremely full and feel like my stomach is about to explode, but my mouth is craving more. I've been stressed out with graduating soon, but I'm getting the most of my anxiety from how out of control so quickly my eating habits have changed and how bloated my body has gotten within just a month and a half. I see a therapist weekly and we talk about how I eat as coping for my anxiety and she gives me suggestions on mindfulness and how to approach situations without turning to food first, but in the meantime I wanted to know if anyone that is currently experiencing any recovery from binging and purging habits on what you do. I'm extremely proud of myself that I have not purged since I was home for winter break, but I am worried that if I keep up this binging/mindless eating habit that I am going to end up purging again. What do you guys do to help you from not mindless eat, see food and just eat it- eating has literally consumed my thinking for the past two years, I genuinely haven't been able to enjoy a normal day where I go a solid period of time without thinking what I am going to eat next, especially in a setting like college and away from home.   I would like to say that I am not trying to purposely lose weight (even though that would be nice), but rather I understand that once I have a grip on my eating, then the weight will come along with it. I just would like to hear from fellow recoverers rather than my therapist and my parents on how to cope and not be tempted to grab food impulsively when I'm tired or bored, or also how you guys handle stress and anxiety in general. (Sorry if some of this sounds repetitive - I don't talk about my history and current anxieties of binging/purging with any of my friends... not really something I ever talk about out loud about except my therapist and family, which isn't too often for how often it bothers me)

column5:
So last month was my “ana”versary as I like to call it. This time last year I was being NG fed and I was very unwell. I had FBT and I was weight restored re fed ect and started to feed myself without restriction. However In December I started exercising and losing weight. Since then I started school again and stopped eating much at all. I’ve lost weight since then and I’m feeling the mental effects because my AN is very happy and feeling VERY restrictive. Because I’ve been through this before, I’m more aware of what is going on, I’m not in as much denial because he’ll, I know where I’ll end up if I continue. My daily habits normally are unhealthy. All term I told myself that I’d maintain my weight a bit under my healthy weight, but classic ED saw the number drop and boom she was hooked. I’d also walk around having conversations with her, she’d say “it’s ok, when it’s Easter holidays you can stop, just restrict until then, then you can eat.” So I believed her, and I ate normally and without extreme guilt for one day, and then 2 days later and I am restricting, exercising and feeling constant anxiety. I knew my mum makes breakfast on Sunday’s, so all Saturday I had to restrict. What I’m trying desperately to say is I want to get better this time, I truly do! I’ve forgotten what it’s like to be healthy and recovered, it’s been too long. I want to be able to eat without guilt so badly, but I feel like I’ll never be able to overcome my rules and regulations around food. I have things I must do based on weather, activities, time of day, day of week, mental state ect. I can’t imagine ED would EVER let me eat on a day or time where I can get away with restricting because no one is watching.
So I need help. How do I let myself eat for the holidays? Like I can eat, but the guilt is immense. And the fear and anxiety leading up to it is so crippling that I don’t even taste the food let alone enjoy it. I’m scared guys, and I FRICKING WANT TO BE ABLE TO EAT why is that so bad? ED just had a huge go at me for saying that, but at least I can say it right? That’s gotta be better than last year. I just wish I had someone who understands and can help get me through this, someone who can tell me that I won’t die if I eat certain foods.
Thanks guys, hope you’re all doing ok and just know that we can get through this together, food ain’t the enemy.

column5: Hi Everyone! After continual comments of concern from friends and family about my weight I know I need to make a change.Weighing a certain amount and being a certain height, I know I DEFINITELY need to gain weight. With help from my family I’ve planned to start ‘bulking’ however I just can’t force myself to do it to any big extent. As soon as I eat a certain amount of calories in a day (an achievement anyway) I think okay, I’m not hungry now, ive eaten a normal persons calories so I’m fine right?I know full well that those calories have still been meticulously planned and bare all my same restriction patterns. However when I actually eat it feels easy to do so as I do it, I just can’t push forward and to eat a certain amount of calories I know I’ll need to do gain weight.Basically, I know I need to gain weight objectively, however in my mind I don’t see that I really need to? As soon as I eat and stop feeling cold for a bit I think... nah i’m actually fine, I’ve eaten a certain amount of calories and more today, what more do you want from me? I’m just tall so probably why I look skinny.I just can’t get my head in the mentality to eat when I’m not hungry or to let myself tackle fear foods just happy to eat lots of calories of what I choose. I realise this post is basically just me ranting to myself, I just can’t accept that I will really need to bulk up? But at the same time know that I DEFINITELY NEED to change my mindset. I think that if I eat a meal and aren’t hungry afterwards... my body can’t be that bad otherwise I’d want more?I guess all I can say is thanks for listening haha - god help me

column4: Having Surgery - No Exercise for a certain amount of time...HELP!
column5: I am scheduled to have surgery at the end of April and have been told that I won't be able to exercise for at a certain amount of time. I suffered from Anorexia then Bulimia for much of my young adulthood and thought I had recovered but, over the past 5 years, ED has reared his ugly head. I am very restrictive in what I eat (or rather, don't eat) and cope with things by exercising. The fact that I feel so compelled to exercise is what scares me. I'm facing surgery at this point because I did so much damage to my body by over-exercising and not giving my body any rest. I am choosing this time after surgery to focus on real recovery. I will do the work all over again and reach out for professional help if needed. What I am hoping to find on this forum is support during what I know will likely be the most difficult thing I have done so far. I am trying to see it as an opportunity for my body to heal and also for my mind. I'm absolutely petrified. What will I do when I can't even do a certain exercise for a certain amount of time? I never just sit and do nothing. If anyone has ever been though something like this, please tell me how you got through it and anything that you found helpful. Thank you so much for reading my post. Christin

column5: Hi everybody, I feel like I keep being angry but because I can't deal with the anger except by pushing it away (and eat). In my life I never felt ok to be angry or to express anger. I was always afraid I would hurt anyone by it or that something bad would happen to me if I did. Now a days if I'm angry I just push it aside and pretend everything is ok.  but basically I say to myself I'm not important. yes this is the message I got in the past, but it doen't have to be like that anymore right? But how to get rid of anger? If I don't agree with something or if something is bothering me, I say this in the nicest way. (after some debate with myself on how or if to say it). I take the anger out of the picture. Afraid to do something wrong or for example losing my job or something. Like I'm afraid to get angry.Is there a safe way to practice with this? I tried boxing in the past, but I don't feel like I can get to the angry part of me. So basically I'm just doing the punches and kicks without any feelings. This is like not productive for the anger I have. Still because I put away all the feelings and makes me eat because how much can a person take? (And still feel I have to be able to take everything) Also I keep reading about 12 steps, could that be something to start with? If yes, do you have a little information about this since I don't live in the US. Thanks for listening X

column4: Severe Toe Pain and Really Hating It Controlling my Exercise Routine
column5: Plus I am around the apartment more until this heals and feeling more tempted to open the fridge and eat food out of boredom and NOT just because I feel hungry. I had been doing so well. I was walking 4x per week after work, my weight was down and felt Totally in Control in spite of having binged a few times as well. I was binging out of feeling tired from working my 2 jobs, and the exercise was the way I forgive my self for this bad habit...Now i feel powerless and cant go for de-stressing walks until the pain in my toe subsides. I also cut into my finger as I was planning to eat my Little Cutey orange the other morning.They are supposed to be easy to just unpeel the skin of their oranges, it is like an orange well know for this primary benefit in eating them.I have low blood sugar in the morning and take meds at night so in the morning i appreciate Lil Cutey Oranges as they are Usually easy to peel and eat.Well, I had to use a steak knife to cut the orange. I somehow disassociated for a few seconds and next thing I know I was stopping myself from cutting into my index finger which was supposed to be holding the orange from slipping as i cut it.So I was bleeding and now am recovering from a cut usually not ever possible when eating lil Cutey oranges. I think someone in the factory thought they would be wise jerks and put the wrong oranges into the lil Cutey bags as the bag said it was them but these all have skin which requires a knife to open and eat.So there now I feel more intimidated in eating healthy food in the morning. Plus my weight is up and i am feeling extra anxious over this factor too.

column5: Everything irritates me! Kids, bugs, husbands, dog pooped, EVERYTHING!!!! Only things that matter to me, my husband, (Together 12 years a Slave! Just joking, 11 1/2 years. Doing Comedy helps me cope and keep my disease secret) my secretary job, my mom, my two dogs Cupcake and Brownie and Comedy, in that order. At home, my dogs need me (because I feed them), but my husband acts like he doesn't need me (I feed him too, but I guess kibbles and bites makes you more appreciative), and how can I blame him. Oh and I'm only an administrative assistant at work, so you know how many suits see me here, NONE!) I've been purging since I was 11. I'm 33 now and half a woman. Normal BMI and weight for my height most of the time, but my body's been falling apart over the years. I've lost teeth, my hair won’t grow and has been falling out so I were wigs all the time, I've never came on my period (I'm afraid it’s because of purging at such a young age) from the lack of hormones my body produces, my body cannot produce eggs, see half a woman. I bruise and bones break so easy now. I reached out to a treatment center in Maryland, and have an assessment coming up on April 5th, 2019. Just told my husband and my mother I have an eating disorder, and that was the toughest thing I've ever done. Needed them to know because they don't deserve to lose me unsuspecting and not knowing what was happening me. My heart been acting funny, but I ain't laughing! The closer it gets to my treatment center assessment date, I've been purging more, like I'm secretly trying to sabotage myself from life. Food is my enemy and it killing me, but it use to be my best and only friend, my comforter. I can't wait ‘til April 5

column5: I am really suffering from what a doctor said is a stomach ulcer and I am concerned for my overall health, when I should be feeling great because I have 7 months free from restrictive ED behaviors. I have had several "flare ups" causing me extreme nausea, feeling excessively full after small amounts of food, throwing up acid, stomach pains, dizziness, and this morning I passed out twice trying to get to the bathroom, scaring my mom who thought I was having a seizure. I only remember standing up the first time I passed out and then sitting on the toilet, I have no recollection of the second time I passed out at all. I do suffer from low blood pressure, which has caused me to pass out from standing up too fast in the past, and could of gotten up out of bed to abruptly I suppose. But today I am again suffering a flare up, and now have pain on my left side like a side ache from exercising, every time I breath. My concern is this issue has caused too much of a weight loss, and this passing out was a result of my body being too weak. I don't own a scale so I don't know what I weigh, and I have been thinner in my disorder, but I can tell I am lower than I should be to be healthy. I ate a solid and healthy dinner in spite of the nausea and pain it creates, but that was all I managed to get down all day. I am very disappointed because I am truly in recovery finally, and yet I feel worse now than I ever felt in my disorder days. I have a follow up appointment next week to try and get to the bottom of this ulcer with tests, and finally get  the correct medication to manage it. I was at first triggered by the sudden weight loss with thoughts of trying to maintain this lower weight, but I have used the many tools I've learned to just acknowledge such thoughts, and let them pass with no acting out on them so far. Before this ulcer I was at the gym again finally, starting to feel strong and fit again. Now I can barely get through my shift at work, needing to sit down to catch my breath several times from standing too long. So that's my problem now and I wonder if anyone out there has ever dealt with an ulcer before, and got through it somehow better then I am so far? I at least passed my state exam and am officially re-certified as a Drug and Alcohol Counselor again. Sorry for such a long post to ask a simple question, but I needed someplace to express my disappointment and concern for my health. Thanks
column9: s.boewer, although you are under the care of a physician, the symptoms you mentioned are very concerning.Because your post mentions health concerns, the following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit or any other serious medical concerns.If you experience anything above, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911.Thank you, take care.  - NEDA moderators

column4: I can't tell if I need help
column5:
I can't decided if I have an eating disorder or if I need to seek help. Here are the reasonings I might have a problem:
spend hours a day thinking of food and my body
worried if I eat an unhealthy meal
always will pick the healthiest choice
watching what others eat closely and judging them (I can't always help it)
making sure I only eat the healthiest food, and get very concerned when I can't be healthy
 ex: inner panic when my mom made certain foods one night
lose weight every time I am at school even though it isn't intentional (I'm in college)
     - in general I find that i am I a lot more concerned about food at school
     - I began this school year at a certain weight but now am even less
workout as much as possible
always cold
very dry skin (but I also live in Wisconsin and its winter)
constantly critiquing my body imageAt the same time, I don't know if I really have a problem because after I mentioned all of this for the first time to my mom, I stopped worrying a little. The thoughts above come in waves and in the long run I just want to make sure I am eating healthy food and working not, my goal has never been weight loss. its not every night that I need to have a justification to have dessert or another snack, but at least half of the time I do. I really don't know if there is something wrong with me that I should get help, or if this is just normal to have fluctuations like this. Does anyone have any advice or a similar experience?

column4: Update about the process of recovery and considering about different ways
column5: It has been while, my processing of recovery became very difficult, everything is behind, I haven't finished work on my projects, I'm too engrossed with my body image, count calories, the fear. Like I did write the calories down on my papers, I'm continuing worry about my body image, It is changed but it making me feel not satisfied with this, and continuing to check the scale every morning. Yesterday, my mom brought foods, it made worse, because I looked at the foods, think about the calories. I still do chew and spit since, I hate it, but I felt like I has to. Today, I want to try to do cheat day, but somehow, I started to feel panic as the fear of gain the pounds if I eat anything I want to. It was very horrible. I'm considering about how to recovering and get my self-esteem and confidence back, I'm thinking about joining the kickboxing, or weight lifting, I don't know yet. I want to do yoga too. I think it is maybe helping me better with my eating habits like not restrictive food, I want to have felt comfortable with food and my self-esteem and confidence. I need to do something. What do you guys think of that? It would help since I can't afford to have treatment.

column5:
This post is mostly a rant about how I'm frustrated with myself today, and doesn't really have a point. Perhaps it would have been better not to have posted it. If so, I'm sorry.
-------------------------
I have struggled with bulimia and bouts of restriction off and on for about 13 years. For about the last five months, I have been restricting, which is worrying my husband of 11 months. Over all, he's supportive, and I am grateful for that. I'm sure it isn't easy for him dealing with me constantly changing my mind about what I want to eat, how much effort I am willing to put into getting better, and whether I really have a problem.He is helping me schedule medical appointments, which is quite helpful. He also sometimes asks how I'm feeling about food. I usually don't say much, because I'm not sure my feelings would make sense to him, but lately I have been making an effort to be more honest. So couple of hours ago, I mentioned to DH that even though I know he wants me to eat more, I feel embarrassed eating in front of him. His reply: "Objectively, it's more embarrassing to be eating as little as you are".
I found this rather depressing, and haven't done much since then except sit in bed feeling alternately hurt by his lack of tact, guilty for worrying him to the point that he feels the need to talk to me like that, and ashamed of taking such a little comment so personally.Part of me realizes I am being a bit overdramatic and ridiculous and should just get on with my day, but another part-- maybe the ED?-- wants to use this as a reason/excuse to drive the restriction more undercover and hide my feelings more. I guess I feel kind of alone and confused and unsure of what to do.

column4: New Here! Feel like my journey to recovery has paused
column5: Hi All, I'm new here on the forum and wanted to post to get some perspective about my thoughts recently. I have suffered from a very difficult relationship with food since the age of about 13. Since that age, i've spent periods of my life dieting (going to slimming classes with my mum, signing up for online programs, trying fad diets), thinking that I needed to lose weight. I was never "stick" thin, but I always thought "if I just lose a bit/if I just tone up/if I just had a bit of a flatter stomach...then i'd feel comfortable". I've spent as long as I can remember thinking that I'm not good enough yet - instead of enjoying my life, i'd been sitting there, pre-occupied, tense from worrying about what I looked like, and dizzy from not taking deep breaths due to anxiety it was causing me. At the age of 22, while visiting the doctor about the anti-depressants i'd been on/off for since 16, my doctor referred me to an eating disorder support service. I thought I always had an issue with food, but I didn't think I had an "eating disorder", especially as I thought there's nothing wrong with me, I just "can't lose weight and it's MY fault, no wonder i'm a bit out of control". I never realised that my relationship with food and my body could actually be the source of my difficulty.Now in my mid-20s, I've found my time at the support service has been positive (1 yr talking therapy, 1yr occupational therapy, and now monthly support groups). I haven't stepped foot in a slimming group in over a year and i'm off my anti-depressants thanks to my doctor's support (I realised that my mind needed care and attention through therapy (rather than meds) to change its patterns). Getting help from professionals has the been the best choice i've made. However - (of course there was going to be a "but", because no process ever runs smooth), i've run into a lot of anxiety recently wondering about the direction of my progress. Despite now refusing to diet ever again (I will not go back there), it's hard thinking positively about what i'm achieving and i'm terrified i'll again be driven to restrict my eating in some way. My actual weight seems to be the No. 1 pain-point. I've always been in the healthy range up until I started therapy, where I began to stop dieting, and now I am at a higher weight. While i've been thankful for less mental pressure, and more "free" feelings towards food (less of the good/bad labels I used to use), my mind is still pre-occupied with my weight and "feeling fat". Now my weight is technically over the recommend amount, I feel scared and confused of how recovering from an eating disorder and reaching a healthy weight can go hand in hand. While i've maintained my weight for 1yr now, I'm terrified that i'm not reading my scales right (I weigh once a week as was recommended to me, to show myself that I can maintain my weight WITHOUT dieting), and i'm even more irrationally scared that my therapist was maybe reading different results out to me this past year, so that i'd think I was maintaining my weight. I'm looking for advice about how reaching a healthy weight can be possible after/while in recovery for disorderly eating.
column9: Hi jbusani!Welcome to the forums! Just so you're aware, your post has been edited slightly to remove mentions of specific numbers that may be triggering to other users. You can review our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines Thanks, and continue posting!
column13: Hi, jbusani, since you mentioned feeling dizzy we just wanted to post up the signs and symptoms of a medical emergency. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitOr any other serious medical concernsIf you experience any of these, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911.

column5: Hey, guys, so I restricted today and was feeling extremely dizzy and like I couldn't really catch my breath so the feeling of my body sounding its natural alarm systems made me feel just a hatred for my body and it not allowing me to fully restrict in the way that I wanted too. A friend of mine that I shared my struggles with ED really pushed me to get out of my comfort zone and do something I didn't really want to do and I just got done eating a lot of food plus Desert food and now I feel really uncomfortable and I really want to purge because I just feel anxious about gaining so much weight in such a short amount of time. But I'm trying to become more comfortable with feeling uncomfortable that my body is satisfied. It's also a little frustrating because I don't know what "satisfaction" means without engaging in ED behaviors. I'm just completely over "EDDY" (Nickname for ED behaviors).I honestly think that diet culture is so harmful when in the process of trying to recover from an ED. For example, ever since I was a child my mom was always chasing a new diet or a new juice cleanse and I honestly believe that through that and through seeing those behaviors even to my adulthood today really shaped the way, in my young mind, my relationship to food and to my own body. there's always been a disconnection there. Even when I went home for a break from school, All my mother would talk about is her new diet and how good she felt, how fat I looked and how I needed to stop eating to lose some weight, so recovery is doubly hard because it's like a mixed messaging thing. it's just so frustrating.I'm sorry if this message is really long, I'm sorry if this doesn't make any sense or mentions specific foods I ate. I'm in a really vulnerable state right now. I don't really know what I'm trying to say nor are my intentions are to trigger anyone into a spiral. I'm sorry.
column9: Dear Notsickenough22,You mentioned that you were feeling dizzy. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature ofless than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitWe recommend that you seek medical help as soon as possible. You can also reach out to the NEDA Helpline (https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/help-support/contact-helpline) for treatment options.

column5: So I BDD dropped dangerously low in weight, several sizes in 7 months and in kids know. I have BDD, depression, health issues that I have to watch my diet and I need to get back on and I just figured out that this is too related to stress, major stress. My father passes I losses alot of weight,bad break ups loss weight, childhood loss weight,bf goes off to rehab I feel like ive been abandoned and lose weight!! See lose major weight,plus I have chronic pain everyday.  First I blamed him for looking at other girls and the type of girls he was following and that triggered me and I was thinking oh my gosh is what what he wants & or actresses he picks out are thin and thinking is that what he wants!! Then I wanting to get into modeling well that didn't help.  Im almost 40 years old plus my health diet is strict, plus stress Stess Stress and thinking Im never gonna good enough for him or my brain telling me Im not skinny enough or telling all kinds of thinks!!  Are you kidding me!! Jeez!! No!!  I compare myself too.. I miss my old body!!  Darn it!! I cry and I cry and Im in meds for depression, the treatments Im going through for my health arent working and Im upset and Im wanna just quit so bad! Just throw up my hands and say Enough Already give me a break!!

column4: Routines and Rituals Rule My Life
column5: I have a tenancy to enjoy familiar patterns in my daily routines. I wash hand b4 eating, of course. I walk. I only seem to like the same type of snack foods, and meals seem to always be a safe type.I'm trying to maintain and ultimately reduce my weight and water retention. I  am currently super bloated and finally seem to have gotten my period after 2 months having skipped and yet had PMS for all the time b4 it returned to haunt me again. I'm in my early pre-menopausal yrs so I hate my periods. They are heavy and irregular. It goes against my need to have dependable routines in my life. I cant plan to wear say my favorite white dress when I'm not sure when the period is due. I am afraid to change my daily routines and rituals either. My life just seems to be secure the way it is and changing may just rock my lil boat into an undertow at sea and that could be even worse than a few good routines in my life.I mean,   I awaken daily 6 AM. I eat breakfast at 7 AM. Off to work daily by 7:15 AM. I am on the way home by late afternoon. Then I either go straight to my 2nd job or am home to rest and take an evening walk after dinner and then check my emails online, etc b4 bed, oh and catch the eve news too by 8 PM. But, to me, this is all good...

column5: I have bulimia. It started out as anorexia but after binging with my friend it has turned into bulimia. I had anorexia for about 6 months then after my binge I’ve been binging and restricting and such ever since. I’ve been bulimic for 5 months and I’m so over it. My situation is a bit weird. My natural BMI growing up was always super low and I always got made fun of for it. So I started to eat way way too much to try to gain weight. Then I started losing it again and here I am. I’ve gained again from binging. I want to overcome it and I always have the mindset and then I just lose it and binge. I haven’t made it a week without messing up either by not eating or overeating. I’ve been trying so hard since January now. I can’t even go to anyone in person because technically I’m still underweight. But if I wanted to gain weight I’d want to gain weight from eating healthy not overeating one day then undereating the next. How do I tell myself this is the final time? It’s becoming so hard for me because now that it’s been 5 months my body is starting to adjust to weighing more making it harder to lose weight as it’s no longer just sitting as food or water weight but actually sitting. I never keep it up it seems like it’s taking me forever to lose it. And I can’t even go a week without binging. Help?
