column5:
Hi,
I've been singing and purging for a certain amount of time now. I was doing it more frequently and then less frequently. But with school just starting back up I've had a certain amount of episodes. I've never experienced an eating disorder before. When I get the thought to binge it is all consuming. And even though I know I won't feel better afterwards, I still can't stop. I've told my boyfriend about it, but I don't let him on when I've had an episode. So he doesn't know how often I do it. I work 3 12hr shifts of the weekend, and am in nursing school the other 4. I know I should find a therapist, but I dont really know where to start. I don't live in a well populated area that has many people that specialize in ED. I guess I'm just looking for some advice. Or to learn from other people who are in recovery.
column9: Hi Newgirl,We are glad to hear that you are finding support here on the NEDA forums. A portion of your post was edited and deleted due to the mention of specific numbers and behaviors. Our community guidelines are always available to review here: http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines. In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST).

column5: Hello! So just recently I have realized that I have an eating disorder. For the last year I’ve lost quite a bit of weight and my whole family became concerned and my fiancé’s family as well and it wasn’t until people outside of my family and friends started to say that they were concerned that I realized that I do have an eating disorder. I feel very nervous around food and try to eat the lowest amount of calories I can in a day. I’m not servely underweight but I’m close to underweight. I feel very bad and sad and I cry a lot. I want to feel good about food again and I feel like nobody in my family really knows how it feels for me. They are so supportive especially my parents but I feel like I don’t have anyone to talk to that really gets it. I do have an appointment to see a therapist that specializes in eating disorders but I can’t get in until mid feb. just thought I would try to come on here where people have been through similar situations. I’m trying very hard to eat more and get back on track but it’s veey hard and I keep slipping up.
column9: Hi, ms.ex, welcome to the forums! We're so sorry to hear that you have come to the realization that you have an eating disorder. It must be really hard to feel like you can't open up about what's been going on! It sounds like you feel like those around you are supportive but you're not quite sure how to open up! Maybe this page on our website can help: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/sharing-concerns-about-your-eati.... Hope you can find the support you're looking for while you wait for your appointment with the eating disorders specialist! If you need any additional help, please feel free to reach out to the NEDA Helpline at (800) 931 -2237 (Monday - Thursday 9 AM EST - 9 PM EST Friday 9 AM EST - 5 PM EST) or chat with us (top right hand corner). Please also take a look at our community guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column5:
Hello Everyone,
I am bulimic and have been for 5 years. I realize How bad this is for me.  I would have times I wouldn’t purge but recently realized I have to stop. I haven’t had a episode in a certain amount of time. However, I am overweight. I want to get healthy and lose this weight the right way. I used to be able to lose weight quickly when I was eating healthy and exercising. In a certain amount of time I have been eating healthy and exercising and every time I get on the scale I’ve only lost a certain amount of weight. I’m really afraid I have completely messed up my metabolism and didn’t know if this is normal? Have others suffering from bulimia and trying to lose weight the correct way had this problem? If anyone has any insight on this subject I truly appreciate it as it  has been a real struggle not to purge.
column9: Hi Tarheel1486,We are glad to hear that you are finding support here on the NEDA forums. A portion of your post was edited and deleted due to the mention of specific numbers and behaviors. Our community guidelines are always available to review here: http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines . In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST).

column5: I’m not sure what people really share about themselves but my name is Mandy, I’m 24. Originally I had bulimia starting from 6th grade but managed to conquer it on my own and by going to a group at my high school. I guess I just never realized that instead of fixing it, it turned into something else that took me until very recently to truly accept which is binge eating disorder. I have state insurance and I know very few places that would actually be helpful that would take it so I’m turning to this forum to help me understand it. I’ve been on meds and in therapy for most of my life but have managed without either and was doing well for close to 5 years but now I’ve realized what I’ve been pretending isn’t there. I have all the tools to help myself and I don’t have a problem setting up a healthy meal plan, understanding good food is most foods, and I know restricting isn’t the answer and all that. After reaching my highest weight in ever essentially I realized I need to buckle down and make changes, which I did in a healthy way, for almost three months. I was losing weight at a healthy rate, eating until I was satisfied instead of boardering sick but then I went to Florida in October and it all fell apart. I guess being out of what in my mind was in my control was too much and now I’m back to eating ridiculously large amounts of food, in my opinion, until I’m sick and feeling depressed, anxious. I thought it was just a funk but it’s been a couple months. I’m fighting to make baby steps and not give up but I’m not really sure how to fix compulsive eating. I know this was a long post but I’d really really appreciate everyone’s thoughts.

For more information on the community guidelines check here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines Cheers

column4: Insomnia Wed Morning 4:43 AM, then EARTHQUAKE jolted me out of bed
column5: I'm here in California and this morning early $:30 AM-ish i couldn't sleep last few hrs. Then suddenly a big shake from my bed. Then looked upon epicenter web site and it was centered in Berkeley, CA @ 3.7. I nibbled nervously b4 bed and during the middle of the night as if nervous that something would occur, then it did. Was excited from earlier when i browsed at Costco and saw sooo many nice jeans and soft material leggings. Trying to plan my winter wardrobe to go w/ boots and jeggings, long parkas, or winter coats. I want to be prepared like a Girlscout for the fierce rains to come this season...Planning ahead for me is both exciting as well as stressful...I haven't been binging much since my molar was chipped. I did slightly purge. Nervous about work today too, no assignment scheduled as of yet for today. This always seems to make me extra anxious...
column9: Hi, chunkymonkey68, a portion of your post was edited and deleted as it contained details that might be triggering for members on the forums. Please take a look at our community guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column5: Still being told that I'm fat and need to lose weight. It's really upsetting and it's making me not want to eat at all.Only thing encouraging me to eat is my mum and dad. They're my rocks at the moment.I could really do with some support.
column9: Dear Karenc,It sounds like you have described a symptom of a medical emergency. The following are just some of the other signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention: • accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury • become suicidal • confused thinking and is not making any sense • delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there) • disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are • vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea • experiencing dizziness or fainting spells • too weak to walk or collapses • painful muscle spasms • complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing • blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit • a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16 • an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute) • cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitIt is important that you seek medical attention immediately if you experience any of the above symptoms. If you cannot contact a medical proffessional you are already in contact with, we reccomend you call 911.

column4: Mindlessly Eating and Managed to Candy Crush a Tooth Colored Filling
column5: This week I have done a few things mindlessly. I went out the door Monday to work w/o having taken any of my daily rx's, chomped down on a binge food, during a mini-binge and broke a cosmetic filling in my tooth which was not cheap to have restored the 1st time the tooth was"Restored" I stepped on the scale and was further stressed to see my numbers were up quite a few above my "Acceptable" area for a safe weight for my "Comfort Zone." Probably a post-binge consequence, oh well.... I have begun to exercise after work again. Remember my foot had problems for a MONTH that caused me to stop---ENTIRELY---from any walking exercise. God did that feel awful. A month w/o any exercise, except picking up clothes off the floor and fitting rooms at work. As a result, I am now, having to sweat over this weight gain resulting a month later...I'm just feeling powerless, and really grossed out until I begin exercising again, a few times a week, i guess???? I now am also dealing with a scratchy abrased eye which I don't have time to go and see a Dr for eye drops about. I'm praying hard that God will just heal my eye as soon as possible and save both me and the eye Dr unnecessary time from this eye abrasion bordering my grey iris and the cornea next to it. Pray for my healing, please... I had childhood type nightmares last night of being the tag along, kid sister, and running away from "Killer Bees" that were chasing me each time I would enter the front door at a relatives place of employment when i was like 4 or something. Kind of feeling 4-ish and powerless currently and hope my day today goes better...Amen. P.S. I did receive a raise at work so that's a plus which doesn't put me into a tailspin over numbers...
column9: Hi, chunkeymonkey68, we just wanted to let you know that a portion of your post was edited because of specific details that might be triggering for others. For more information you can take a look at our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines  Additionally just wanted to post up this resource in case you need it now or in the future: Text "NEDA" to 741-741 or www.crisistextline.org

column5: I've read many posts here but haven't found any that relate to my current situation. I began outpatient treatment in the fall but was eventually recommended for a higher level of care. I am terrified. I previously recovered with only outpatient therapy and my own will power, as I could not afford any additional resources at that time, and there were no alternatives available in my city at that time. So when I relapsed recently and sought help again, I had no clue higher level of care might be necessary. I'm basically not allowed to remain outpatient. If I don't agree to IOP, then I will be kicked out of the treatment center where I've been receiving help. I like my therapist and believe she has helped me immensely, and I'm confused and distressed about being forced into making this decision. I haven't found my sessions with the dietitian to be helpful at all, and I don't think I can follow the rigid guidelines and schedule of IOP. I don't even know if I am ready to or want to. They have told me there are no unexcused absences allowed at all. I don't know how I can keep up with work and all my other obligations in addition to spending 14 hours a week in IOP, plus travel time. I have no support from friends or family. I know this is a wonderful opportunity to finally conquer my eating disorder--one that was not previously available to me, and that many other people lack access to. But knowing that doesn't help me feel differently. I honestly feel like all the stress around IOP is making things worse, and I am tempted to just quit, but I'm also afraid of what might happen when I am completely alone again.Has anyone else experienced this type of high anxiety around treatment? Do you have any tips or advice for how to conquer these feelings? I am supposed to start later on this week, and I feel like support from peers might help me to make the right decision.
column9: Hi, deuxchartreuse, we're sorry to hear that you're worried about treatment and feel unsupported. We're glad you felt comfortable reaching out here on the forums. Our community guidelines are always available to review here:    https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST) or chat with us!

column5: I had been noticing my body looked bigger and got it confirmed at my doctor's appointment when they put me on the scale that I am X pounds overweight. I decided to eat a bit less, but soon that turned to eating next to nothing. It feels as though I have no options. On the one hand, I don't want the negative health effects of anorexia, and on the other hand, I constantly feel disgusted with my body and it feels unbearable to live with my body at this weight. I feel I need the weight gone ASAP, and so I feel it's required to eat an anorexic diet. I'm so scared of this condition getting a grip on me again. I don't want to harm myself. Does anyone have any advice?

column4: do i have an eating disorder?
column5: I think i have an eating disorder but i’m not sure. I am quite obsessed about my weight and body shape. I feel and view myself as fat even though i am of normal healthy weight. I obsessively count calories and get agitated if i don’t know the exact amount of calories in something. I try to only eat a certain amount of calories a day. Every time i eat something that doesn’t seem appropriate i try and try to engage in behaviors but I can't, I physically can't do it no matter how hard I try and it makes me very upset. I feel guilty disgusting and shameful eating normal foods. I have passed out from lack of food before. I get pretty upset when people tell me to eat and i lie about eating and i say that i’m counting my calories to make sure i eat enough when i’m desperately trying to restrict my calories. I get such a sense of accomplishment when i lose weight and i get very upset when i put on weight no matter how small. Do i have an eating disorder?
column9: Hi lydstar,We are glad to hear that you are finding support here on the NEDA forums. A portion of your post was edited and deleted due to the mention of specific numbers and behaviors. Our community guidelines are always available to review here:   http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines . In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST).
column13: Hi lydstar,  Since you mentioned  that you have passed out from lack of food before, we just wanted to provide you with a list of some signs and symptoms of a medical emergency. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit or any other serious medical concerns. If you experience any of the above, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911.

column5: Been in PHP for a little over two weeks. I am pretty much having to look into Residential because they cant help me. It took so much in me to make myself go to PHP and now this is happening. I am terrified. Also, has anyone ever restricted and not lost weight for a period of time? My weight will not budge even with my lack of nutrition. I don't understand. I feel like I don't even need to go to residential because my weight is fine. I just want to scream. I hate going to therapy for 10 hours every day. I have been so depressed and honestly been feeling worse since I started treatment. I want to give up, I want to disappear.
column9: Hi, confusedasf, we're sorry to hear that you're scared about treatment. Since you mentioned that you want to give up and disappear we are concerned about your safety. This number is really important to have: (800)273-TALK(8255). We would like you to contact that number. If you don't feel comfortable talking, please text "NEDA" to 741741 or visit one of these websites: http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ or www.crisistextline.org/get-help-now http://www.dialhelp.org/?page_id=7759 or text 906-356-3337 http://unsuicide.wikispaces.com/Online+Suicide+Help+Wiki#.UcNaxKwfHt0https://www.imalive.org/ or call 800-784-2433

column5: Hi Guys, Thought I would finally reach out and just hear it from an outsider..., A little bit of background - I have been suffering with manic depression for the last 14 months, on the right medication now and have seen so much improvement in myself! I come from a healthy family - and we all loved our food. Me especially! For the past X months I have dropped a lot of weight - everyone is noticing and saying things - not all positive comments either. I think I am a healthy size now and because I was on the larger scale - I now look ill.... Rewind to when I was 15 - at high school, I used to make myself sick - because I loved food that much, I couldn’t diet and that was my way of controlling my weight... so being sick has never bothered me... I have food allergies which I am not very strict on, and would make me vomit, and then vomiting became a habit. I don’t like feeling full, I don’t like never being hungry. The doctors have diagnosed me wiTh Nervosa bulimia - but I am in a battle with whether I agree or not, I look at myself and think “no love, you do not have an eating disorder" Please help!

column5: I'm struggling to believe I have any worth.  I wonder if anyone would miss me.  Maybe they'd be better off without me.

column5: Please help I feel like I really cannot go without exercise I’ve been trying so hard to cut back but it’s all I think about... it’s like I just NEED it or else I will actually go insane it’s driving me crazy I just want to spend a normal holiday with my family and not just be thinking about working out all the time... please help I am so miserable and wondering what the point of life even is... I can’t live like this anymore

column5: If we text "NEDA" to 741741 do they understand eating disorders and can they make us feel better? Because I went onto 2 teen helplines because I had the feeling of binge eating again and they didn't understand. It made me feel upset, started to cry and I left and I did my best not to give into the feeling. I wish everyone would get this.
column9: Hello iwanttolive and london1621, we wanted to let you both know that the crisis text line (741741) is not staffed by NEDA volunteers. The crisis text line consists of trained crisis counselor volunteers. They are there to support you through crisis. NEDA has a helpline (800) 931 - 2237 and chat service (on the top right you should see "chat now") where we can provide some support, information, and resources!
column13: Hi, iwanttolive, we're glad that you no longer self harm! However, we are required to post up the resources whenever they are mentioned in case anyone else on the forums needs them so they are aware that there is help out there!  Crisis Text Line: Text "NEDA" to 741-741 or www.crisistextline.org/get-help-now S.A.F.E: (800) 366 - 8288 or www.selfinjury.com

column4: Need some help or reassurance with weight gain in initial recovery
column5: Just kinda looking for reassurance or something to stop the crazy in my head a little... so I’ve been properly trying to eat more the last 5 days and I tried to just eat what I wanted yesterday for Christmas but for some reason I decided to weigh myself and I have gained weight. I mean I know a lot is food weight and I’ve not ‘gone’ properly since starting and I’ve read when you first start eating more your body holds on to it all.... but I can’t help but freak out and my husband isn’t really sure how to reassure me (‘it’s fine though, it’s Christmas and you know you can’t really have properly gained that much ‘)Somebody please reassure me or help me or just spew facts at me? I’m giving myself a migraine and I don’t want to try anymore
column9: Hi HopefulTot, Welcome to the forums! Your post was edited slightly to remove specific numbers and behaviors that could be triggering to other forum members. The forum community guidelines can be found here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelinesWe hope that you continue to post!

column5:
I’ve looked everywhere, but honestly, I’m so confused. So I’m coming here as a last resort, because I can’t just go to the doctor’s on my own.
For years, I’ve been engaging in behaviors to dispose of my food and eating very little.I will however, have lunch on days where people could tell if I wasn’t eating. Though when I don’t have lunch, I’m usually around friends, but I could really only call them acquaintances at best. On the days where it’s be obvious if I didn’t eat, however, I’ll tend to make it look like I ate by engaging in behaviors to hide food.
The habit of hiding food started earlier this year. The rest has been going on since before I knew it was wrong. But now, I almost feel glad I have these behaviors. Like it’s a preventative measure of me gaining weight. I’m not underweight for my age, according to my BMI. I’m definitely on the lower end, but I’ve never been in the underweight range. But I still feel I’m not good enough. I need to be skinnier. Most of all, I can not allow myself to gain weight, though I’m barely hanging in there. I don’t exercise really at all. Nor do I purge, or binge. This is what’s throwing me off the most. I do none of that. But most of the day, my stomach is rumbling,  even though I’ve always eaten this little.
But that used to be an innocent habit. Now, I realize what I’m doing, and want to use it to my advantage, to stay at my definition of a desirable weight. I’ll engage in behaviors to hide not eating if I have to. It’s hard to hide, especially with a horrible memory, preventing me from remembering where I hide half of the food anyways. But I try. I don’t know if this could even be classified as an eating disorder, despite all the research I’ve done. I’ve even taken official tests, suggesting Bulimia, but the actions don’t apply.
I suppose this information may help as well. I have been diagnosed with GAD (Generalized Anxiety Disorder) and have been feeling quite depressed this past month, and have had... dark thoughts. I feel so many things are wrong with myself. Though I’m concerned with grades (despite being one of the highest in my class) and my position in life, my weight is one of my largest concerns.
Here’s a quick recap:
-(Barely) healthy weight
-Eating very little, and behaviors to dispose of food
-Desire to stay under weight, and getting upset at self when I get closer to that number, trying to find clever ways to avoid eating food without others noticing
-Not feeling good enough for anyone, despite
I truly thank anyone who replies. I really need help, to know what to do. I see a therapist for my anxiety, but I know she doesn’t specialize in this, and I’m just too scared to tell her anything, because I don’t want people finding out. And I can’t just go to the doctor myself, because I’d need to schedule an appointment through my parents, and that’s just requiring me to face one of my largest fears... But I’m scared. I want to try and fix this before it’s too late. Again, thank you to any who reply.

column4: Possible tool for avoiding temptation and relapse -- would like feedback please!
column5: I was doing some online research about binge-eating disorder because I am an active binge-eater and have been desperately trying to break out of my current binge-eating cycle and figure out how to prevent getting stuck back in one. I just stumbled onto a concept that I think may be immensely helpful and immediately wanted to share it and hopefully get some feedback about how to use it. Briefly, let me explain the concept and how I stumbled onto it. Then I'll tell you how I've started to try to use it. Basically, all humans, and especially addicted humans (whether it be a food addiction, drugs, gambling, whatever), are susceptible to preferring an immediate award over a delayed, larger award. In other words, it's very tempting to choose to receive $5 now rather than get $30 if we wait 10 days.  (Substitute whatever rewards and lengths of time make sense to you.) The scientific term for the behavior of preferring the immediate, smaller award is called "delay discounting". We are "discounting" the "delayed", larger reward (whether it be more money or staying sober) in preference for the immediate, smaller reward. This is not the concept that got me all excited and prompted me to post here. What got me all excited is the concept that's scientifically called "explicit-zero reframing". I had absolutely no clue what that meant and had to read and learn about it, so let me break it down. By reframing the choice, it is made explicitly clear that if we choose the immediately available, smaller reward that we will not get the delayed reward. Of course, intuitively, we understand that already, but studies have shown that when a choice is presented using explicit-zero reframing, people "exhibited significantly lower levels of impulsiveness". We are able to resist the impulse and choose the delayed reward! As I said, I got excited and immediately wanted to share the idea, so I haven't really done that much research about it yet. So here's how I've started to try to apply the concept... If I'm driving home from class (I'm a college student) and am tempted to stop and buy food and engage in a binge, here are the ways I could think about the choice: a) bingeing: The pros: I would get temporary relief by numbing my feelings by occupying my mind with food-seeking, eating, and feeling sick afterward. Additionally, because I would feel sick afterward, I could justify not engaging in behaviors later that day like going to the gym, hanging out with friends, or whatever. The cons: I would be mad at myself and feel sick and overly full today, stay stuck in my binge-eating cycle b) not binge today: The pros: I would be proud of myself and feel good today, and make progress toward breaking out of my binge-eating cycle The cons: I would not get that temporary relief that makes me feel horrible afterward. I really think by forcing myself to think about the choice to give in to temptation and binge using the explicit-zero reframing might actually help me! Of course, I'm instantly flooded with internal thoughts like "yeah, but you'll be tempted all over again tomorrow and might make the wrong choice and then what's the point?!". Obviously I'd have to be very conscious about ignoring those thoughts and considering the choice objectively. And presumably, it would get easier over time and with repetition... Well, what do you guys think? Obviously it's not the answer all by itself, but it seems to me that it could be a very powerful tool in my recovery toolbox!

Where do I fit in? Are they diagnosing me in an intake evaluation? How intense is it? I’m really scared out of my mind. I’m 54 years old and struggled for 38 years.

I can't believe that I started using food to help me to be okay after something horrible happened and now I can't stop binge eating. Why did I do this to myself? Why am I so stupid for doing this? I don't want to do this anymore. I get so upset and depressed after. I went onto this teen helpline chat and she didn't understand what binge eating was and I got upset and left. I don't want to give in.

column5: Hi, I'm new here and I just wanted to ask a question regarding amenorrhea.I lost my period a couple months ago and my doctor said I need to gain some weight to get it back. I'm not even sure that I have an eating disorder, just that I restricted calories enough to lose my period. I'm technically not in the healthy BMI range yet, but I'm really only a little bit underweight and I've been told that BMI is pretty inaccurate, anyway. I haven't even gained that much since my doctor told me to, but I am no longer anemic and my mom seems to think that I'm at a healthy weight. I still haven't gotten my period back though, and I have to admit that it makes me feel a little weird that she's telling me I can stop trying to gain now just based on how I look and the amount of time that's passed. Should I keep gaining until I get my period back? Or keep going until my BMI is technically healthy? Or should I listen to my mom and eat normally except for an extra snack? I might still naturally gain weight even if I'm not trying, just because I'm eating more than I used to, but it would probably be a really slow process. I know that none of you guys are doctors, but I'm just getting a lot of mixed messages and was wondering if anyone had experience with this kind of thing that might be helpful.Support to everyone here who is struggling :) you guys are really brave

If you notice that you're struggling with anything on this list, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another options is 911.

column5:
I have just joined the Neda forums, and I was disappointed to choose the "working on recovery" forum, rather than the "maintaining recovery" forum.  Since receiving treatment for the first time in 2011, I have been consistently motivated to stay in recovery.  I had a few slip ups over the years that lead to iop or day treatment, but those were mostly due to self harm/SI rather than ED behaviors.  Last spring was the first time I felt like I had a real ED relapse, and I was still able to treat it in day and iop.  During that relapse I felt so awful i swore "never ever again" would I do this to myself.  Already though, I am really struggling.  I have never relapsed so soon after treatment and I am feeling pretty disappointed in myself.  I feel like I just repeated the same mistakes I made in the spring, and I knew better.  I am struggling with restricting, and exercise urges though I haven't really been acting on those a whole lot.  I want to do better, I just feel so afraid to eat what I know I need to.  I feel stuck and like I need more support to get back on track.  I think iop might be helpful, but I absolutely can't take anymore time off of school, so it would have to fit into my schedule next semester.  Additionally I work with a client who has special needs in the evening and I feel so guilty to take more time off from that as well, because I feel that her family really needs me.
I am wondering what others have done during times of relapse, especially if you were able to turn it around on your own.  Ive only been struggling for about a month, so I still feel hopeful that maybe I can do this just with the help of my outpatient team.
column9: Amb28, we are sorry you are going through so much right now. We are glad you are here and able to write about everything, and hope thatyou find comfort in knowing how many people care about you! Because you mentioned some concerning feelings you're having we just wanted to post some crisis and suicide prevention resources in case you or anyone in this forums needs them: Crisis Text Line: Text "NEDA" to 741- 741 or www.crisistextline.org/get-help-nowNational Suicide Prevention Lifeline: (800) 273 - 8255 or www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org

column4: Tracking binge or binge free days - helpful or harmful
column5: I have a binge eating issue and tonight was a bad one for me. I do this a few times a month and while it has bothered me for years only in the past month have I started acknowledging it as a possible "disorder". Using the word disorder and suggesting that I may have a borderline eating disorder seems to make my family and friends finally start taking my comments concerning this struggle seriously. It also makes me more motivated than ever to pursue healing and growth and to finally tackle this. So, to get to my question, do you think there is any benefit in tracking days where you have binged or not? The diagnosis for having a binge eating disorder states that it has to be repeated weekly for three months. I know I binge eat a couple times a month but its hard for me to say truly how often it is. I thought tracking it on a calendar might be good for my own awareness... but I'm hesitant thinking that I'd be inadvertently focusing on how often I binge, which is surely something I don't want to reinforce.

column5: I don't know if I have an eating disorder, I've never felt the need to categorize my eating habits. I had my first baby this year. I gained a lot of weight during pregnancy and I'm having trouble losing it. I hit a plateau a couple months ago and nothing I did would kickstart the weight loss. I also suddenly became very busy with work and I work an odd shift so my meal times are different than most people's. I started eating less due to being distracted/busy and noticed I lost a bit of weight. I got excited and decreased my intake even more. I should also mention I take a prescription that also acts as an appetite suppressant, and some days I take more than my prescribed dose. I've been very happy with the results but I've noticed when I eat something I haven't had in a while I'll get sick. I had junk food and immediately got sick, I was up all night. Last night I had more junk food and it was the same thing. This morning I was getting nauseous and didn't want to have anything too heavy so I took a few bites of something bland and had to run to the bathroom to vomit. I don't know what's going on with my body, I'm nauseous from not eating but eating makes me sick. I don't know what to do.
column9: Hello and welcome to the forums Jis18! Your post was edited slightly to remove specific numbers and mentions of food that may be triggering to other forum members. You can find the community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelinesHave you also taken a look at some of the resources the NEDA online website has? The NEDA Eating Disorders Screening Tool can help determine if it is time to seek professional help. Here is the link to the Eating Disorders Screen Tool:https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/screening-toolAlso, up in the upper left hand corner, under the "Help and Support" link, you can find the "Where Do I Start?" There are a lot of resources under this link that can help you take the first step to getting the help you deserve if that is the path you decide to make. Here is the link to that one too:https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/where-do-i-start-0Since you mentioned you feel like you're struggling with digestive issues we wanted to provide with an additional list of signs and symptoms of a medical emergency to keep an eye on:• accidentally or deliberately causes themselves a physical injury• becomes suicidal• experiences confused thinking and is not making any sense• experiences delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• feels disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomits several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiences dizziness or fainting spells• feels too weak to walk or collapses• experiences painful muscle spasms• complains of chest pain or having trouble breathing• observes blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• has a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• has an irregular heartbeat or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• has cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit Or for any other serious medical concerns. If you notice that you're struggling with anything on this list, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another options is 911.

column4: Need some support to stop binge eating
column5: Hi guys,I'm a 22 year old male and I have a problem with binge eating, when I binge it is usually high calorie and X time(s) a week. It has been happening for three years now, with the only off period being for around 3 months, two years ago if I recall correctly. Recently I opened a business and the stress is impacting me and I am starting to binge more, each time I beat myself up and tell myself how to stop it and that it's emotional but inevitably I go back to binge eating. My weight and fitness is very important to me and as a result I am not overweight, but the binge eating is stopping me from reaching my goals and each time I binge I cannot bear to look at myself. I usually binge in private and I hide this from my family and close friends, I have only told a few people but they aren't here to support me. I am the kind of person to say that I should stop being a wuss and just to grow up, but I can't find a way to stop this cycle and this bad relationship with food using that approach.I wonder if there is anyone here who shared the same experience? Maybe this will make me feel better as I feel often quite alone in this and like it's something wrong with me. Thank you all for your time, Chris
column9: Hi, iwanttolive, we just edited your post because people can call or chat with NEDA, not text! But thank you for letting users know they can reach out to NEDA.
column13: Part of your post was editing because it included a specific number. Please take a look at our community guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column5: I've been thru recovery but it was for being primary anorexic with occasion binge/purge.  I relapsed into binging/purging and have become severely laxative dependant.  I'm in a position where I can't take laxatives now and I have horrible pain everywhere from swelling and bloating, I can't get in to see my doctor until the 17th, does anyone have any ideas on how to get some safe relief from the swelling until I can get into my doctor?
column9: You mentioned some concerning symptoms, tryingbutconfused. We wanted to provide you with a list of some signs and symptoms of a medical emergency. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitOr any other serious medical concernsIf you experience any of the above, we recommend seeking help from a medical professional as soon as possible. Another option is 911.

column5: Hi guys, So basically I am relapsing in my eating disorder again and it is slowly progressing and getting worse. And I know I should ask for help, but I don’t know where to start getting help. Like I’m practically starving myself, obsessing over calories, cutting certain foods from my diet, I’m losing weight, my chest is now starting to hurt whenever I move about for more than 5 minutes. All I do is obsess over food even if I can’t bring myself to eat it, I’m constantly tired all the time from like lack of nutrition I guess, and lots of other stuff too. I know my next step is to look for a program to start when the New Year rolls around (insurance and scheduling makes it hard to start sooner) but I just need support until then because the fact that I’m realizing how bad this is, is sending me into a depression.
column9: I'm so sorry you're experiencing these feelings and experiencing a relapse. Because you mentioned some concerning feelings you're having we just wanted to post some crisis and suicide prevention resources in case anyone in this forums needs them: Crisis Text Line: Text "NEDA" to 741- 741 or www.crisistextline.org/get-help-nowNational Suicide Prevention Lifeline: (800) 273 - 8255 or www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org Also reiterating what iwanttolive mentioned in her comment, your physical symptoms are concerning, and we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911. Additionally, we will put this list here just in case you experience any other concerning symptoms. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitOr any other serious medical concerns

column5: I got an assessment done at an eating recovery center and they recommended PHP for my level of care treatment. This has only freaked me out even more and caused all my behaviors to worsen. There is no way I need PHP, I feel so embarrassed because I am disgusting and I feel like I won't belong in that level of treatment. I am just so ashamed and confused. I feel like I am pretending to have a disorder but then I think about how miserable and crazy it makes me and then I just feel overwhelmed and dissociated.  I went multiple days not eating this past week and have barely left my appt or left my bed. I am so tired, im so sick of not knowing whats going on in my head and im sick of having to struggle with doing a necessary human task. How do I know if I have an eating disorder even though my therapist tells me. I know she would not lie but I also feel so scared she thinks I am an unhealthy weight(which im not) and thinks its something way bigger than whats going on. I don't even know if this post made sense but the thoughts in my brain don't really make sense so I don't know why I thought they would on here. Anyway, wondering if anyone relates because im feeling confused and alone.

Just because you mentioned some concerning feelings you're having we just wanted to post some crisis and suicide prevention resources in case anyone in this forums needs them: Crisis Text Line: Text "NEDA" to 741- 741 or www.crisistextline.org/get-help-nowNational Suicide Prevention Lifeline: (800) 273 - 8255 or www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org Additionally, please take a look a look at this list and see if you have experienced any. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitOr any other serious medical concerns.If you experience any of the above signs and symptoms, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911.

column5:
I don't know what's happening, I've been binging almost everyday for sometime. Today I weighed myself and I panicked because I gained weight and I'm at my highest weight I've ever been. I'm not overweight yet, but I'm sooo afraid I will be if I keep doing like this, also because I'm short and not so skinny. I know restricting would cause a binge-restrict cycle, that's happened before, but I am also afraid of eating normally, because once I start eating I don't seem to be able to stop. I lose control especially when I don't have school, because I'm home, there's more food around, and I live with my parents, who always cooks certain food. That's also the reason why Christmas holidays, which will be in two weeks terrify me, I'm afraid I will binge and gain a lot of weight.
I don't know how I can stop this, I noticed going out doesn't help, because I will eventually binge when I get home.
I just needed to vent, but if anyone has any advice it will be appreciated....:(
column9: Hello, we wanted to let you know that part of your post was edited due to specific details/numbers that may be triggering to others. Please take a look at our community guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column5:
I’m struggling to fight this monster. I’ve had my ED for 9 years now. I went inpatient 7 years ago and was okay for a year maybe, then it got really bad again. Last year I had two ER trips that scared the hell out of me and I decided to try recovery again for real. I’m still trying and I still want recovery so bad, but a year into the fight and I just wanna throw the towel in. My nutritionist, DR and therapist have been talking about treatment again in the last two weeks, mostly cause after Thanksgiving and with Christmas coming up my anxiety has been so high that my behaviors have increased. I know that if I set my mind to it, that I could do it outpatient, but I’m afraid that the ED voice is just so loud at times that I might not be able to handle it.
I stumbled along this forum while looking online for some sort of inspiration to keep going. Wishing everyone the best :) thanks for letting me get some things out.
column9: Welcome to the forums, kelseyalora! We are glad you are here and hope that you find the support and community helpful to your recovery. In the event that you need further assistance, please don't hesitate to reach out to the NEDA helpline @ 1-800-931-2237.

column5: I was doing so well, staying on my Healthy Food regime. Then PMS hit and even after MS I'm still CRAVING for this specific junk food. I feel guilty and Undisciplined to be craving this specific food. I even did well around Halloween time but this is like a wave hitting me and thrusting me into even deeper ocean waves just as i come up for air i am tossed and turned into a wave of all waves. Finally, until i am saved by a calming water and then no wave at ALL.  I swim in from the sandy beach which i finally being washed ashore to and only then do I feel clean and safe all over Again.... I don't ever plan to return to the ED inpatient which I had to stay at during the Summer. It was not realistic, and the boundaries just aren't there for me in my real environment here at home in my small suburban apartment in California, USA....I have a fridge, and a stove, and cabinets w/ food and when my cravings hit sometimes its just difficult to deal with. Thank God for my journal, and for the walks, I take to relax from the temptation to binge....
column9: @Chunkymonkey68 - Your post was edited because describing ED engaging behaviors is against our community guidelines. Thank you.

column4: Working 2 Jobs, can Be exhausting to me so...
column5: I'm currently experiencing laryngitis and stomach pain. Just finished shopping for HEALTHY food at the store. These are the 1's i cant order online. I hate spending so much hard earned money on food. I hate myself when i get a full-fledged craving for certain desserts and end up wasting money on junk foods which i very rapidly consume and then feel quite horrible over having wasted money...  I'm sorry if some post readers have a Problem w/ my mentioning how my periods are affected by my ED. However, I am a female and do have period problems which ...I think really are affected by my ED-NOS type, and very HEALTHY and picky eating styles, most of the time, except during binges...  Its the truth, i am NOT writing to harm anyone. I wonder about women's issues, how they affect me and my body, and also enjoy helping to support other mature forum writers here too...

column5: I have had an eating issue for quite a while, 20 year plus. This includes uncontrollable eating, especially junk food. Everything has been binge related.I have also tried every method possible to drop weight when this happens, or to stop thinking about food, including intermittent fasting and so on. I have been a personal trainer for alot pf this time, so I know nutrition very well. Not alot of help in an eating disorder situation still.I am not going to go on much, yet 20 years is a long time with no let up. Over the past 12 weeks, all signs of binge eating has gone, and this is what i have done. Sure it may come back, though with daily urges, to now zero, i am happy, and if you haven't you may like to try this.When stress is high, which may be from work, general daily things that agitate you, thinking about food all day again, or even from having coffee "especially", cortisol which is a stress hormone in your body rises, and this can effect appetite stimulation alot. Other things that effect cortisol, is not eating after working out, when your body is looking to recover, and especially from higher intensity or weight training. As cortisol builds from any of this, you are more likely to binge eat.

I’ve done groups, four therapists, nutritionists, medications, DBT, and I just don’t seem to have the will to stop. Where do I go from here?

column5: I don't even know where this belongs. I've never been diagnosed with an eating disorder and maybe I’m in recovery. Three years ago I decided to go on a diet for all the wrong reasons. I’ve struggled with body issues my entire life and this seemed like a way to drop weight in an instant. I lost a lot of weight- I looked great, people told me I looked great and it was awesome. I wasn’t eating the right foods and quickly became very sick; I had horrible digestive issues and cystic acne for the first time in my life.I didn’t want to stop because I didn’t want to gain the weight back. Finally, I realized I needed to fuel my body better. I went to a nutritionist and was told I was “sensitive” to many foods. It was basically a free pass to never eat. I felt emboldened by this assurance from a professional that I couldn’t eat a lot. I lost so much weight. I secretly loved it. I never told my friends that I loved it; I complained that I was too skinny and really trying to gain weight. I got a boyfriend and went on birth control and gained more weight. My body began to change and here I am. I weight less than I did before I went vegan but more than when I wasn’t eating. I have a horrible relationship with food and my body. I still don’t eat certain foods (more for fear of getting larger than for acne or digestive issues). I have never really told anyone this. My doctor asked me a year ago if I thought I had an eating disorder and I said no— I think about that a lot and wish we talked longer about it. I went home and told my sister and she laughed and goes, “I don’t think you have an eating disorder.” Now that I’ve gained weight and am seemingly better on the outside I don’t think anyone would even believe me if I asked for help. I just know I don't like my body-- I lift up my shirt and look at myself in the mirror over X times a day. I question everything I eat and feel really guilty about eating bad food. I guess I just want someone to listen.

column4: a hopeful first step to stop binging
column5: Hi, everyone. I'm new here, and I think that it's time for me to confront what I've been ignoring for a long time. I started dieting in eighth grade because my Taekwondo instructor wanted me to lose weight. I was competing at a national level and very committed, so I did what he asked. At that time, I was a healthy weight at the time but a little on the chubbier side. I lost the weight but then I kept losing weight even after I had reached a weight that my instructor was happy with. When I got to high school, I kept restricting calories in an unhealthy way until everything seemed to fall apart half way through ninth grade. I had problems with my friends and school, and I felt so lonely. I began eating more and started feeling better. I kept slowly gaining weight every year and began binging. I felt so embarrassed that all of my friends could see that I was gaining weight and I was depressed. But I always found comfort in food and started binging more and more and I've finally reached the point where I'm ready to stop. I want to lose weight, but I'm more focused on just being healthy again. I've gotten really out of shape because I'm scared of going to the gym, but I want to get over that and start prioritizing my health. I don't know where to start, but I thought that this might be a helpful first step. I also wanted to thank everyone else for sharing. Reading your posts has given me hope and helped me see that this is not something that we have to do alone.

column4: Somebody Please call 911 For My Out of Control Binging...Lately
column5: So as I had mentioned earlier. Around this time of the year, I suppose I cave for food, more easily.Its warm, and comforting while I'm cold, and just arriving home from work, and feeling extra anxious.I find myself, shopping for binge food after work. All of the foods I buy are meticulously surrounding me with my best binge treats. I think I need the help of my local fire-paramedic crew to extinguish my horribly bad habit of this, after-hours, food frenzy cycle which I am currently entrapped with…So, I was enjoying all the willpower which I have exercised up until this month. Finally, I'm almost over a period that was 2.5 months late, and am back to binging a certain amount a week after a cold, or stressful day at work.Just having to travel from point A to point B, actually triggers my anxiety and binging a certain amount each week.

column5: Hi. I'm new to this forum and relatively new to acknowledging that I have an eating disorder. I called the hotline yesterday and found out about this forum. I am a compulsive exerciser and calorie counter. Right now my body fat percentage is very low but that is also because I am an ultra-marathoner. I don't really want to or intend to stop exercising or running. It makes me feel good. I am a recovering alcoholic and I also have bipolar disorder, and I'm a former smoker, so running seems to be a much healthier habit. The problem is that I can't eat without immediately feeling like I need to work off all those calories on the same day. Last night my parents made me dinner at their house and then I ran in place while talking to my dad so I could work off the calories. Dad said it makes most people anxious to see me bouncing around in place. I work 58 hours a week and also have other obligations, so often I'm running late at night or exercising very early in the morning. It's an obsession. The calorie counting is a real problem too. Right now I can tell you that by 3pm I will have eaten a certain amount of calories (because I know what's in my lunch) and then before job #2 I'll eat and track and then after job #2 it will be more of the same, which is way over my self imposed limit for the day so I'll have to go home and run in place. It doesn't make sense, because I'm underweight and my body fat is so low it's off the chart. I don't need to be working this hard to keep my weight low, but I can't help myself. It's an obsession and it gets in the way of "normal" life. Sorry, I know a lot of this sounds like venting and it's a little too much for one post. But does anyone have a similar experience or any advice to offer?
column9: Hello, part of your post was edited because of numbers and detailed descriptions that may be triggering to others. Please be sure to read our community guidelines for more information: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column4: Scared my insurance will deny coverage
column5: Hi All, I've struggled with bulimia for the past 12 years, and am finally starting to get myself professional help. I am seeing a therapist and working with her to figure out the best course of action, but I am very seriously considering a more intensive form of treatment, either a residential program or intensive outpatient programAn intake rep at [treatment center] contacted my current insurance (through my employer) and found out treatment would be covered, I would only be responsible for my deductible. She did mention that this is no guarantee, and that at day of admission when the pre-auth claim is submitted, my insurance could deny the claim. My biggest fear at this point is that I will be emotionally ready and also make arrangements in my life to go to a treatment program, and then be denied. Has this ever happened to anyone? I know [treatment center] often petitions on a clients behalf if services are denied- does anyone have any experiences with this? Any insight or advice is appreciated. thank you

column4: I want to be binge free
column5:
Hello everyone!
I'm new here. I've heard that it's more likely to achieve a goal if you share it with someone. So that's me sharing my story.
I've been suffering with several eating disorders for about 5 years now. Last year I've made a lot of progress. There was time that I used to binge eat every day. Thanks to my parents and my boyfriends support I learned to dismiss urges to binge. Or I thought so. I used to overeat once a week at that time but still, it was a great accomplishment for me.
But things changed few weeks ago. I moved out and changed my university. I don't know if it's because of stress connected to moving to another country or because of me and my boyfriend breaking up, but my binges came back. I'm hopeless now. I thought that this nightmare was over. Ofcourse there was some weight gain too. Right now I don't even see any motivation to try again to fight the urges.
I'm here because I remember I was much happier when I was binge free. Maybe someone else experienced relapse, maybe someone also is a BE eater. Please let me know. We can support each other.
column8: Hi Steff, I am sorry that you
column9: Hi Steff, I am sorry that you are feeling hopeless now.  Asking for support regarding eating disorder recovery is wonderful, but I'm also concerned for your safety and I wanted you to be safe.  Please contact the Suicide Hotline at 800-273-TALK if you are feeling suicidal. Please also consisder contacting NEDA for resources to aid your recovery! Helpline 1-800-931-2237 Chat at www.myneda.org Text "NEDA" to 741741

column5: Hey all! I've been working with a online e-coach/nutritionist/dietician, as my time is available (I just took a new job and am moved to a hotel to live for 2-3 months, until relocating again!!) Needless to say, it's been a frenzy (but good for change and outlook!) Anyhow, I haven't had a chance to set up an e-appointment this week, and had a quick question. Not looking for expert/medical advice, but just your experiences. I’m EDNOS, and (luckily?) find eating dessert like foods for dinner easier on my tummy and higher-cal (all "wins" IMO, towards weight restoration chances.) Anyhow, I've found that this early on, I really cannot eat normal sized portions yet. In place of this, I'm using certain foods on top of the small amounts I can digest. Also, I plan to drink a supplement with each dinner too. Is this OK to do without feeling guilty for not being able to eat a full meal, yet? I put a lot of pressure on myself, and this feels like "cheating" to me (I've read things that say, "suck it up, it's gonna hurt, gas-bloating, etc!!!") But, to me, until I can tolerate this without throwing up (accidentally) or causing refeeding, as long as calories are high, it still counts, right? Also, is it OK to use something like Zantac at the "larger" meals everyday, if I feel I need it. If it helps make me want to eat, I'm not against it (always has in the past), but I don't wanna bind myself up or become tolerant to it. Any tips? Thanks again, keep fighting everyone!
column9: Hi there,Questions like these are best saved for professionals such as your prescriber and nutritionist, though the forums are available for more general support.If you are in need of referrals, please consider contacting NEDA for resources to aid your recovery!Helpline 1-800-931-2237 Chat at www.myneda.org Text "NEDA" to 741741 Additionally, we edited some parts of your post because they were too detailed. Please take a look at our guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column4: Thought I was recovering but I was getting worse
column5: Hello, I am new here. I decided I wanted to get healthy and lose weight about 6 months ago, but I ended up developing a mild eating disorder when counting calories, restricting, and overexercising took control over me. I realized that I had an extremely unhealthy relationship with food three months ago but I still wanted to lose weight. About a month ago I decided that I had enough and I would stop tracking macros and start intuitive eating and take a step into recovery. However, there are certain times I cannot stop myself from eating, and I don't know if I should just keep listening to my body or if it is just mental hunger. I have certainly overeaten a couple of times but I wouldn't say I really went to the point of full-on bingeing to the point I'm so stuffed I can't move or that I ate food I didn't like. For me, it was just eating foods I like and perhaps overdoing it a little. However, recently I realized I started gaining some weight after those days I overeat, and sometimes my weight goes back to normal in a couple of days due to water retention, but overall I did gain a very small amount of weight. I know I shouldn't worry about it but to someone with an ED it is very triggering and I started purging this weekend. I have purged X times in the last X days and I never used to struggle with purging before. I have purged probably a total of X times in the last X months until this weekend. It is really scary to me and I feel like if I listen to my body too much I will end up bingeing and purging. I am so stressed and I thought I was getting better but apparently not.
column9: Hello,Your post was edited to remove numbers that could be potentially triggering to other forum users.  NEDA community guidelines can be reviewed here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines Thanks and please keep posting!

column5: I'm 14y/o and I've only suffered from anorexia for 2 months and am now on the road to recovery. Since I've only suffered for such a short time, does that mean that I haven't done much damage to my body? Should I be eating as much as most guidelines say I should? And would I experience extreme hunger? Because I've been eating a lot recently and I'm not sure whether it's extreme hunger or I'm just bored. Since I'm a teen I'm not sure whether I should be eating more or less than adults. Now I'm eating a lot and I'm using anorexia recovery as an excuse and I'm pretty scared that I'll continue to do this forever. And should I be exercising during recovery? I don't have anyone I know that knows much about eating disorders, even my school counselor seems to know nothing about it so I kind of feel like I'm going through this alone and I have so many questions! Please help me if you know the answers to them!
column9: Hello and welcome to the forums Yasmin. Your post has been slightly edited so that it adheres to the community guideliness. Users are discouraged from sharing specific numbers. https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines    Thank you and pleasecontinue posting.

column5: I was recovered for a full year with the occasional slip, but this is my first relapse and it just started. I was triggered by weight gain. I have behaviors like chewing gum and drinking water to avoid eating, skipping meals, fearing foods, obsessed with food, hiding my body (even from my boyfriend), etc. I'm lightheaded often and dread all the physical, cognitive, and social effects of relapse. I want to be recovered, and, at the same time, I can only get myself to eat a little bit. My body shame is the worst it's ever been. The first time I recovered, I did so on my own. It was relatively easy because I did it slowly. When I chose to recover last time, my fear surrounding fear foods was so minimal. Now, it's more like terror. I don't know how to recover this time. I feel scared.
column9: Hi KayAreEss, You mentioned that you are feeling lightheaded which is a symptom of a medical emergency. Below are additional signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention. If you are experiencing any of these symptoms it is important that you seek medical attention immediately. Is there a medical professional you are currently in touch with that you can contact? Another option is calling 911.  • accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury • become suicidal • confused thinking and is not making any sense • delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there) • disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are • vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea • experiencing dizziness or fainting spells • too weak to walk or collapses • painful muscle spasms • complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing • blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit • a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16 • an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute) • cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit

column5: I am really struggling with believing all my traumas weren't my fault.  I'm struggling to believe that my body didn't bring on the abuse and traumas.  It's been a rough 2 days. It's making me feel gross, fat and worthless in my body.  I'm just having a really hard time right now.
column9: Hi, savedbygrace. We're very sorry to hear that you experienced such trauma. We do want you to know that there is help out there if you need to speak to someone about what occurred. You can reach out to: Rape, Abuse, and Incest National Network (RAINN) by either going to their website: www.rainn.org or call: (800) 656 - 4673. We also edited a part of your post because it was a bit descriptive. Please refer back to our community guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. We hope you understand and that you can reach out to the above resource.

column5:
Hi everyone,
I am New over here. I finally decided to talk about it. I have been bulimic for the 8 years. And I have been feeling really crappy about myself. I want to stop but I can't seem to. It is so tough and it's been taking an emotional toll on me.

Thank you for posting! Please refer to our community guidlines : https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines Also, please feel free to contact our helpline: (M- Th 9-9 EST F 9-5) 800 -931 -2237 or text NEDA to 741741  we hope to see you continue to post more!

column5: I am about two weeks into not purging. I’m in counseling and have a dietician. We are having Thanksgiving at our house like we do every year. This is the first year purging won’t be an option and I’m freaking out. My heads is so full and I just wanted some advice on how to handle the whole thing. From the food to the people who will be there that either don’t know, don’t understand or just don’t care.
